summary: This measure amends the definition of “psychiatric residential treatment facility,” adding among other conditions that all facility residents meet the certification of need for service requirements identified under 42 C.F.R Part 441, Subpart D.
sponsor: Rep. Frances Cavenaugh (R), Sen. Melissa Thomas Irvin (R), Rep. Jeremy Woodbridge (R)

summary: This measure establishes a task force to study and make recommendations concerning certificates of need, including the following matters: instituting a price increase cap tied to the cost growth benchmark for consolidations; guaranteed local representation of communities on hospital boards; changes to the Office of Health Strategy's state-wide health plan to include an analysis of services and the impact of such services on equity and underserved populations; setting standards for measuring quality as a result of consolidation; and enacting higher penalties for noncompliance; among others.

This measure prohibits certificates of need from consideration unless certain documentation requirements have been met. The measure also gives authority to the commissioner of social services to place conditions on any decision approving or modifying a request for a certificate of need.

This measure modifies the state certificate of need (CON) program to require additional notice of transactions in the community; include support for resourcing experts to evaluate transactions for impact; subject provisions of agreed settlements to enforcement action for violations; and lower the state of mind requirement for violations from “willful” to “negligence” with a penalty of up to $1000 per day of violation. In exchange the state agreed to limit the time for reviewing applications, to exempt certain imaging equipment from CON review, and to issue determinations of CON within thirty days. These provisions are effective October 1, 2023. Note: This is a larger bill that contains several provisions. Other provisions are included in the appropriate tab.
sponsor: Rep. Robyn Porter (D), Rep. Eleni Kavros DeGraw (D), Rep. Tammy Nuccio (R)

summary: This measure exempts birth centers enrolled as a Connecticut Medical Assistance Program provider from the state’s CON requirements until June 30, 2028. The bill also requires the OHS executive director, in consultation with the DPH commissioner and within available appropriations, to study whether this CON exemption for birth centers should be extended. These provisions are effective October 1, 2023.
sponsor: Rep. Robyn A. Porter (D), Rep. Trenee McGee (D)

summary: This measure includes a provision that updates notice requirements for intermediate care facilities for individuals with intellectual disabilities under the certificate of need process, such as by requiring facility closure notices to go to the Office of the Developmental Services Ombudsperson rather than the Office of the Long-Term Care Ombudsman, and requiring the ombudsperson’s office to hold informational sessions related to these closures.

This measure allows parties involved in the transfer of ownership of a hospital requiring a certificate of need (CON) in which the hospital has filed for bankruptcy protection to apply for an emergency certificate of need. Requires the unit evaluating the emergency CON application to consider the effect the hospital’s bankruptcy could have on patients and the communities served.
sponsor: Speaker of the House Matthew Ritter (D), Sen. Martin M. Looney (D), House Majority Leader Jason Rojas (D), Rep. Tom Delnicki (R)

summary: This measure provided hospitals and health care service providers with a valid certificate of need that expired within 30 days prior to the declaration of a public health emergency a waiver from the need to renew the certificate of need until 60 days after the end of the public health emergency. This measure was passed on both an emergency and temporary basis -- The emergency legislation expired on 10/19/2021 and the temporary legislation expired on 5/5/2022.

This measure exempts certain health care services, entities, and equipment replacement from certificate of need and creates a registration system for certain health care entities no longer requiring a certificate of need.
sponsor: Hon. Christina Henderson (I), Hon. Janeese George (D), Hon. Anita Bonds (D), Hon. Charles Allen (D)

summary: This measure amends the certificate of need law to remove the capital expenditure threshold for projects or new institutional health services subject to review. The bill revises timelines for submission of a letter of intent by applicants, and revises timelines and processes for the Department of Community Health's review of applications. The bill also revises appeal processes for the Certificate of Need Appeal Panel after a decision has been issued. The bill revises and expands exemptions from certificate of need review. The bill includes a provision imposing a monetary penalty for noncompliance with prior notice and approval requirements. In addition, the Department of Community Health, with the Office of Legislative Counsel, is directed to review the certificate of need program and submit recommendations to the General Assembly by December 1, 2024.
sponsor: Rep. Butch Parrish (R), Rep. Jon Burns (R)

summary: This measure, among other provisions, exempts the conversion of a critical access hospital or general hospital to a rural emergency hospital from certificate of need requirements. The bill also exempts a change of a rural emergency hospital in licensure, organizational structure, or type of institutional health facility from certificate of need requirements. These provisions are effective March 28, 2023 and July 1, 2023.
sponsor: Rep. Craig Johnson (R), Sen. Jeff Reichman (R)

summary: This measure amends the definition of “ambulatory surgical center” under the certificate of need law and other statutes. The bill exempts cosmetic, reconstructive, or plastic surgery services provided in an ambulatory surgical center from certificate of need requirements.
sponsor: Senate Committee on Health and Human Services

summary: This measure includes a provision that would allow a previously licensed psychiatric medical institution for children (PMIC) that has the capacity to provide up to an additional four intermediate care beds for persons with an intellectual disability to increase their licensed capacity to include the additional beds without further certificate of need review including by the health facilities council. As of 2/21/2024, this measure has been amended to revise provisions unrelated to the certificate of need provision.
sponsor: House Committee on Health and Human Services

summary: This measure relates to boards, commissions, committees, councils, and other state government entities. The bill includes a provision that directs the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), in consultation with the Department of Inspections, Appeals, and Licensing (DIAL), and with the assistance of other interested parties, to conduct a study on the effectiveness of the current certificate of need process. HHS is directed to submit a report on its findings and recommendations to the governor and general assembly by December 31, 2025.

This measure removes birth centers from the meaning of institutional health facility, which would allow health care providers to create, relocate, expand, or offer new services in birth centers without the need to obtain a certificate of need.
sponsor: House Committee on Health and Human Services

summary: This measure requires the Department of Public Health to execute written inter-agency agreements with the Department of Human Services and Department on Aging to affect an increase in the determination of need scores for applicants for institutional and home and community-based long-term care.
sponsor: Rep. Greg Harris (D)/Sen. Patrick Joyce (D), Rep. Robyn Gabel (D)

summary: This measure requires health care facilities that are parties to certain covered transactions to provide 60-day advance notice to the attorney general. Transactions include mergers, acquisitions, or contracting affiliations between two or more health care facilities or provider organizations not previously under common ownership or contract affiliation. Failure to provide notice is subject to a $500 per day penalty for each day the party is in violation. That attorney general may investigate the transactions and may apply for a temporary restraining order or an injunction if the attorney general has reason to believe the facility is engaging in the transaction without complying with the notice requirement. There are no minimum dollar thresholds for reporting under the bill. Filings made under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act satisfy the notice requirement. These provisions are effective January 1, 2024.
sponsor: Rep. Jennifer Gong-Gershowitz (D), Sen. Ann Gillespie (D)

summary: This measure amends the Illinois Act on the Aging. In a provision requiring the Department on Aging to increase the effectiveness of the program, it removes a requirement that the Department ensure the determination of need tool is accurate in determining program participants' level of need.
sponsor: Rep. Bob Morgan (D) / Sen. Mattie Hunter (D)

summary: This measure allows a hospital that owns an ambulance service that is exempt from a certificate of need to provide transport services from another health facility to its hospital is authorized by the ambulance service provider with jurisdiction in the territory in which the other health facility is located. The measure also details certain outpatient categories of care that are exempt from certificates of need and licensure, including primary care centers, special health clinics, rural health clinics, and off-campus, hospital-acquired physician practices. If a city or county government has conducted a public hearing for the purpose of demonstrating that an imperative need exists to provide emergency ambulance transport services within its jurisdictional boundaries, it shall not be required to obtain a certificate of need for the city or county. The Legislative Research Commission shall establish the Emergency Medical Services Task Force to study the provision of emergency medical services in the state, the duties of the task force including a review of the need, or lack thereof, for the certificate of need process for ambulance services.

This measure defines "PACE" as programs of all-inclusive care for the elderly and "PACE service provider" as an organization that provides services for the elderly according to agreements between the provider, CMS and the Kentucky Department for Medicaid Services. PACE service providers are exempt from obtaining a health facility license or certificate of need to provide PACE services. As of 3/8/2024, this measure has been amended to exempt PACE service providers from obtaining a health facility license to provide PACE services.

This measure establishes that certain trauma centers that partner with a university to establish a medical residency program are entitled to the university hospital reimbursement rate for any residency program services. The bill includes a provision that requires that, before acquiring or constructing an acute care hospital, the University of Kentucky, the University of Louisville, or a medical system or college or school of medicine affiliate, must obtain the approval of the General Assembly. Such approval is required in addition to any certificate of need requirements.
This measure amends the Cabinet for Health and Family Services criteria to issue, deny, or revoke a certificate of need.
sponsor: Rep. Jason Howell (R), Rep. Donald Douglas (R)

summary: This measure prohibits the Kentucky Board of Emergency Medical Services from requiring an ambulance service from applying for licensure, within a specified time period, and requires submitting application progress reports after receiving a certificate of need. Ambulance services issued a certificate of need on or after July 14, 2022 can apply for licensure Board of Emergency Medical Services without obtaining a new certificate of need.

This measure requires certain health care providers to be subject to facility need review to determine the need for a new or additional facility, provider, program, service, or bed. The measure requires the Department of Health to establish a facility need review process for nursing facilities consistent with regulations for licensure and for Title XIX of the Social Security Act. The rules and regulations shall include but not be limited to: criteria for review of nursing facility beds to determine if there is a need for additional beds, specific duties of the department to review proposals for new facilities, appropriate methodology for the collection of data necessary for administration of the program, procedures to grant and revoke approvals, and establishment of application fees.

This measure establishes an assisted living residences commission to study assisted living residences and recommend policies to ensure assisted living residences adequately meet the health and safety needs of residents. As part of its work, the commission shall examine and make recommendations regarding regulatory procedures for opening, closing or changing ownership of a residence, including determination of need processes and clustering of facilities.
sponsor: Rep. Tom Stanley (D), Rep. Kate Lipper-Garabedian (D), Rep. Lindsay Sabadosa (D) / Sen. Pat Jehlen (D)

summary: This measure creates exceptions to the certificate of need requirement to include continuing care and continuing care at home agreements.
This measure, effective April 20, 2023, eliminates the state’s Certificate of Public Advantage (COPA) law.
This measure exempts positron emission tomography (PET) scanner services from certificate of need regulations.
sponsor: Rep. Like Meerman (R) / Sen. Winnie Brinks (D)

summary: This measure requires the department of health to assess fees and other assessments for health facility and agency licenses and certificates of need on an annual basis. The base fee schedule for facilities and projects of varying capital expenditure are detailed.

This measure restricts the establishment of a new hospital and any erection, building, alteration, reconstruction, modernization, improvement, extension, lease, or other acquisition by or on behalf of a hospital that increases the bed capacity of the hospital, relocates hospital beds from one physical facility or site to another, or otherwise results in an increase or redistribution of hospital beds within the state. The measure explicitly details which projects, modifications, and construction the restriction does not apply to.
sponsor: Rep. Heather Edelson (D), Rep. Tony Albright (R)

summary: This measure includes transaction review by the attorney general if the transaction is a large transaction. Transactions are specifically defined and involve a range of entities, and transactions that are anti-competitive are presumptively prohibited. The attorney general has the authority to unwind anti-competitive transactions. Notice must be provided for small and large transactions as defined under the legislation. Large transactions require the submission of additional detailed financial information to the commissioner of public health and the attorney general, including information filed with the federal government. Non-profit entities face additional reporting requirements. Minnesota specifically authorizes the use of APCD data to “conduct analyses of the impact of health care transactions on health care costs, market consolidation, and quality,” permits the use of data submitted to conduct aggregate analyses of the impact of transactions with respect to those same factors, and requires the commissioner of health to report periodically on the impact of transactions. The legislation also charges the commissioner of health with studying and developing recommendations on the regulation of conversions, mergers, transfers of assets of domiciled HMOs. These provisions are effective May 26, 2023 or January 1, 2024.
sponsor: Rep. Robert Bierman (D), Rep. Tina Liebling (D), Rep, Zack Stephenson (D)

summary: The measure prohibits certain activities without obtaining the required certificate of need, including: the construction, development, or establishment of a new health care facility; the relocation of a health care facility or major medical equipment unless that relocation does not involve a capital expenditure and is within 5,280 feet from the main entrance of the health care facility; any change in the existing bed complement of a health care facility; relocating one or more health services from one physical facility to another unless the relocation does not involve a capital expenditure and is to a facility within 5,280 feet from the main entrance of the facility; and changes in ownership of any health care facility in which a notice of intent has not been filed. The measure details under which circumstances a certificate of need may be granted.

This measure allows private hospitals, whether in a rural or nonrural area, to negotiate and enter into cooperative agreements, subject to receipt of a certificate of public advantage that is approved by the state department of health, effective March 30, 2023.
sponsor: Sen. Joey Fillingane (R), Sen. Jenifer B. Branning (R), Sen. David Jordan (D)

summary: This measure creates the State Board of Health, which may formulate the policy of the State Department of Health. The Department of Health's duties include the ability to extend and renew expired certificates of need, and to charge a fee for reviewing applications. As of 4/4/2024, this measure has been amended to revise provisions unrelated to the certificate of need provision.

This measure establishes no prohibitions or restrictions on participation in the Medicaid program for the person(s) receiving the certificate of need authorized under this measure or for beds converted pursuant to the authority of the certificate of need that would not apply to any other psychiatric residential treatment facility. Establishes certificate of need exception under certain circumstances for a crossover provider. Establishes a date for a certificate of need be issued to a certain entity in a specific county with a certain amount of beds.
sponsor: Sen. Hob Bryan (D), Sen. Joseph Thomas (D), Sen. Derrick T Simmons (D), Sen. Bradford Blackmon (D)

summary: This measure revises certificate-of-need requirements to include only long-term care facilities and services.
This measure amends legislation regarding the submission of certification of need letters of intent to the department of public health and human services.

This measure increases monetary value thresholds for requiring a certificate of need (CON) for diagnostic centers, major medical equipment, and new institutional health services. Each threshold shall be adjusted using the Medical Care Index component of the Consumer Price Index published by the U.S. Department of Labor for the 12-month period preceding the previous September 1. Additionally, a CON issued for the construction of a health service facility expires if the holder of the CON fails to initiate construction of the project authorized by the CON within the specified time frame.

This measure, effective March 27, 2023, removes psychiatric beds and facilities, chemical dependency treatment beds and facilities, Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment services for children under age 21 receiving care from home health agencies, and the first $3 million worth of replacement equipment in any health facility from certificate of need review. Effective 2 and 3 years after the first Healthcare Access and Stabilization Program payment is made, respectively, the bill also exempts ambulatory surgical centers located in a county with a population larger than 125,000 as well as MRI machines located in a county with a population larger than 125,000 from CON review.
sponsor: Rep. Donny Lambeth (R), Rep. Donna McDowell White (R), Rep. Michael H. Wray (D), and Rep. Chris Humphrey (R)

summary: This measure includes a provision to amend the Nebraska Health Care Certificate of Need Act to exempt rehabilitation beds and acute care beds from certificate of need requirements. As of 3/4/2024, this measure has been amended to revise provisions unrelated to the certificate of need provision.

This measure reduces the time lag between determination of need and actual occupancy thereof, to expedite construction, acquisition, or improvement of mental hygiene facilities for the care, maintenance, and treatment of individuals with developmental disabilities.

This measure requires entities to provide a 30-day pre-closing notice of closing of a material transactions valued at $25 million or more to the department of health and the attorney general’s office, so the transaction can be made public for input. This provision is effective ninety days after May 3, 2023. The legislation also requires 30-day public notice for general hospitals converting to rural emergency hopsitals to allow for a community forum on the impact of proposed inpatient bed closure and input on the process. This provision is effective sixty days after May 3, 2023. The department of health has the authority to issue rules governing documentation requirements and the notice requirements. Note: This is a larger bill that contains several provisions. Other provisions are included in the appropriate tab.

This measure makes temporary changes regarding certificates of need (CON); the changes apply to any CON granted between March 9, 2020 and June 18, 2021. The bill requires the Director of Health to grant a 24 month extension to CON holders to obligate capital expenditures and commence construction for a proposed project, and stipluates that the transfer of a CON prior to completion of the activity for which the certificate was granted does not void the CON.
sponsor: Rep. Jean Schmidt (R), Rep. Sedrick Denson (D)

summary: This measure requires any entity desiring to establish a new psychiatric or chemical dependency service or acquire, lease, or expand an existing service to make an application to the State Department of Health for a certificate of need. The bill details exemptions from the certificate of need program for certain health care providers and facilities.
sponsor: Rep. Jeff Boatman (R), Sen. Chuck Hall (R)

summary: This measure exempts a certificate of need review for any addition, deletion, modification, or construction of current or future state veterans home nursing facilities.
sponsor: Sen. Brenda Stanley (R), Sen. Tommy Hardin (R)

summary: This measure would repeal sections of the certificate of need law that are related to psychiatric and chemical dependency facilities. As of 3/4/2024, this measure has been amended to remove the effective date of November 1st, 2024, and establish an emergency. As of 4/30/2024, this measure has been amended to add to the list of repealed sections under the Psychiatric and Chemical Dependency Facility Certificate of Need Act.
sponsor: Rep. Jeff Boatman (R), Sen. Julie Daniels (R)

summary: This measure removes the requirement under the University Hospitals Authority Act to obtain a certificate of need.

This measure amends the certificate of need law, to require the Department of Health to annually convene a meeting of long-term care nursing to receive input regarding the Department's conduct of surveys, with the goal of promoting cooperation and communication between long-term care nursing facilities and the department. Information provided to or obtained by the Department under these provisions shall not be accessible under the state Right-to-Know law unless it is unrelated to long-term care facility performance, is false, or is independently corroborated.

This measure requires any person engaged in the conversion of a for-profit or not-for-profit corporation as the acquiror or acquiree involving the establishment, maintenance, or operation of a hospital to receive prior approval from both the department of attorney general and the department of health. The measure extends the timeline of approval or disapproval of conversion projects from 120 to 180 days of the application being accepted by the departments, and requires any hospital seeking conversion to apply additional information in their application, including: staffing levels, pension plans, and impacts for affected communities before and after conversion.

This measure modifies the state certificate of need (CON) program to eliminate CON requirements for certain health care facilities. Nursing homes are required to obtain a CON for changes including: construction or establishment of a new nursing home, changes to beds, capital expenditures exceeding a prescribed amount, capital expenditures associated with the addition or substantial expansion of certain health services, offering of a new health service, and acquisition of medical equipment resulting in costs exceeding the prescribed expenditure threshold. The Medical University of South Carolina is required to apply for a CON or licensure for acquisitions of hospital facilities. In addition, a CON will be required for the construction or other establishment of a hospital and a change in the existing bed complement of a hospital until January 1, 2027. The bill also establishes a CON study committee to examine the effect of the repeal of the CON program on the quality and quantity of access to health care in rural areas of the state. CON exemptions are amended for the relocation of a hospital under certain conditions, acquisition of a hospital by another person or health care facility, and crisis stabilization unit facilities. In addition, the bill amends considerations for project review criteria, adjusts the timeline of the CON application process, shortens certain time frames of CON administrative and judicial proceedings, and eliminates the role of the court of appeals. These provisions are effective May 2023.
sponsor: Sen. Wes Climer (R), Sen. Penry Gustafson (R), Sen, Josh Kimbrell (R)

summary: This measure exempts acute hospital care at home programs and services delivered by a licensed acute care hospital from certificate of need requirements. This measure also revises exemptions for continuing care retirement communities.
sponsor: Sen. Tom Davis (R) et al. / Rep. Marvin Smith (R) et al.

summary: This measure creates a health services and development agency that has jurisdiction and powers related to the certificate of need program and develops criteria and standards to guide the agency when issuing certificates of need. The measure increases, from 15 to 30 days, the period in which a party or any member of the health services and development agency may file notice to request the agency review an action of the executive director related to certificate of need.
sponsor: Sen. Shane Reeves (R) / Rep. Clark Boyd (R)

summary: This measure continues the requirement that a temporary healthcare staffing agency presently doing business in the state must provide notice to the health facilities commission identifying its business entity and any controlling person by December 31 of each year, instead of ending December 31, 2023. As of 4/17/2024, SB 2022 has been amended to include a provision that establishes that fees and civil penalties authorized by the certificate of need program, including those currently held in reserve, may be used to defray expenses incurred in the operation of the health facilities commission, rather than expenses incurred specifically from the administration of the certificate of need program. The bill removes the requirement that the health facilities commission adjust prescribed certificate of need fees to provide that revenues from fees do not exceed necessary and required expenditures.
sponsor: Rep. Esther Helton-Haynes (R) et al. / Sen. Shane Reeves (R)

summary: This measure directs the State Health Commissioner to accept and review applications and issue a certificate of public need for a new 90-bed nursing home facility, provided that such facility is located on the property of the former Central Virginia Training Center in Amherst County as of July 1, 2023.
This measure requires the Board of Health to promulgate regulations expanding the expedited application and review process for certificates of public need to numerous additional project types.

This measure requires the State Health Commissioner direct the State Health Services Plan Task Force to develop recommendations for establishing an expedited application and review process for projects which a certificate of public need is required that meet certain criteria.

This measure establishes that CON shall not be required if a medical care facility decides to use on average 10 swing beds per day. Requires the State Commissioner of Health collect swing beds data annually from critical access hospitals and make available to the public.

This measure directs the State Health Services Plan Task Force to develop recommendations for establishing an expedited application and review process for a certificate of public need in a medical desert.
sponsor: Del. Wendell Walker (R). Del. Rodney Willett (D)

summary: This measure amends and reenacts codes dictating which medical care facilities and projects are required to have a certificate of need. Outlines actions in which a medical care facility does not have to receive a certificate of need. Establishes an expedited certificate of public need application and review process for specific projects. Establishes exemptions from the requirement of a certification of public need under certain conditions.
This measure allows critical access hospitals to utilize an average of up to 10 swing beds per day, calculated over the hospital's fiscal year, without obtaining a certificate of public need.

This measure allows the Green Mountain Care Board to waive or permit variances, through March 31, 2023, from state laws, guidance, and standards with respect to certificates of need to prioritize and maximize direct patient care and safeguard the stability of health care providers responsive to the Covid-19 pandemic.

This measure establishes the Office of the Healthcare Advocate shall have the right to receive copies of all materials related to the certificate of need application review, and may ask questions and submit comments to the Green Mountain Board regarding certificate of need applications. This measure includes other provisions not related to certificate of need.
sponsor: Rep. Mari Cordes (D), Rep. Daisy Berbeco (D), Rep. Allen Demar (R), Rep. Francis McFaun (R)

summary: This measure increases the monetary thresholds triggering a certificate of need requirement, and exempts certain activities from certificate of need for those health care services and health care facility projects that are contract awards from the State.
sponsor: Rep. Mari Cordes (D), Rep. Angela Arsenault (D), Rep. James Harrison (R), Rep. Michael Marcotte (R)

summary: This measure extends certificate-of-need (CON) exemptions relating to psychiatric facilities and equipment until June 30, 2023. The department shall suspend the CON requirement for a hospital that changes the use of licensed beds to increase the number of beds to provide psychiatric services, including involuntary treatment services. A CON exemption granted under this bill will be valid for two years. Additionally, the bill extends exemptions from CON requirements for the construction, development, or establishment of a psychiatric hospital that will have no more than 16 beds and provide treatment to adults on 90- or 180-day involuntary commitment orders. The bill also states that psychiatric hospitals are exempt from CON requirements for the one-time addition of up to thirty new psychiatric beds. Lastly, an entity seeking to construct, develop, or establish a psychiatric hospital is exempt from certificate-of-need requirements if the proposed psychiatric hospital will have no more than 16 beds and dedicate a portion of the beds to providing treatment to adults on 90- or 180-day involuntary commitment orders. The psychiatric hospital may also provide treatment to adults on a 72-hour detention or 14-day involuntary commitment order.

This measure allows for an exemption from certificate of need requirements for a kidney disease center to exceed its authorized number of dialysis stations during certain temporary emergency situations, effective July 23, 2023.
This measure amends the certificate of need law, exempting the construction or establishment of psychiatric hospitals and the addition of psychiatric beds from certificate of need requirements.
This measure amends existing law, exempting elective percutaneous coronary intervention performed in certain hospitals owned or operate by a state entity from certificate of need requirements.
sponsor: Majority Caucus Vice Chair Chipalo Street (D), Rep. Nicole Macri (D), Rep. Joe Schmick (R), Rep. Lisa Parshley (D)

summary: This measure transfers jurisdiction over appeals of decisions of the Health Care Authority in certificate of need reviews from the Workers’ Compensation Office of Administrative Law Judges and Circuit Court of Kanawha County to the Intermediate Court of Appeals.

This measure exempts hospitals performing hospital-based services, birthing centers, and certain physician office practices seeking to acquire and utilize one magnetic resonance imaging scanner from certificate of need requirements, effective March 10, 2023.
This measure authorizes the Department of Health to promulgate a legislative rule filed in the state register, authorized under the rulemaking authority of the certificate of need law.

This measure amends existing law that prohibits the issuance of a certificate of need to an opioid treatment program. This measure establishes that an opioid treatment program that is an approved clinical trial for the study of office-based methadone versus buprenorphine to address retention in medication for opioid use disorder treatment may be developed for the limited purposes of and timeframe for the trial. This exemption only permits one program to participate once.
sponsor: Sen. Craig Blair (R), Sen. Mike Woelfel (D) / Del. Roger Hanshaw (R), Del. Sean Hornbuckle (D)

summary: This measure restricts the Department of Health to approving certificate of need alterations or additions of health care facilities for the purpose of healthcare and life safety compliance determinations only. Repeals bed expansion limitations for certain nursing care facilities and hospitals, and requires a report from the Department of Health to a committee on the status of construction of nursing care facilities with certain other information.
sponsor: Rep. Rob Geringer (R), Rep. Martha Lawley (R), Rep. Chip Neiman (R), Sen. Christopher Rothfuss (D)

summary: This measure allows the Department of Healthcare Access and Finance to impose a fine up to $5,000 on hospitals for failing to submit community benefit plans consistent with the law. It also allows the department to grant a 60-day extension for submission. The department will post a report online with information from hospital community benefit plans, including specified details on spending.

Adds racial and ethnic groups experiencing disparate health outcomes and socially disadvantaged groups to the definition of “vulnerable populations” for community benefits reporting purposes. It would also require a hospital to prepare and annually submit an equity report to the department. This equity report must include, among other things, an analysis of health status and access to care disparities on the basis of specified categories, including age, sex, and race, and a health equity plan to reduce disparities. The measure would authorize the department to impose up to a $5,000 fine against a hospital that fails to adopt, update, or submit an equity report, and would require the department to list online those that failed to submit an equity report. The bill would require the department to convene a Health Care Equity Measures Advisory Committee with specified membership to assist and advise the director relative to equity reports.

This measure includes a provision that amends the definition of hospital charity policy. The bill would prohibit a hospital from considering the monetary assets of a patient in determining eligibility for both charity care and discount payment policies. The bill would instead require that the eligibility for charity care or discounted payments be determined at any time the hospital receives recent pay stubs or income tax returns. The bill would prohibit a hospital from imposing time limits for eligibility. The bill would authorize a hospital to waive Medi-Cal and Medicare cost-sharing amounts as part of its charity care program or discount payment program. This measure also prohibits a hospital or emergency physician from using liens on any real property as a means of collecting unpaid hospital or emergency room bills, and prohibits a collection agency from conducting a sale of any real property owned, in part of completely, by a patient or placing a lien on any real property as a means of collecting unpaid hospital or emergency physician bills. This bill would authorize, but not require, the hospital to reimburse the patient if the hospital or the department determines that a patient qualified for financial assistance at the time the patient was first billed and it has been 5 years or more since the last payment to the hospital, hospital assignee, or debt buyer or the patient debt was sold to a debt buyer.

This measure, effective August 7, 2023, imposes certain requirements on the public presentation of each hospital's community benefit implementation plan. Under the bill, hospitals must complete a community benefit implementation plan that addresses the needs described in the reporting hospital's community health needs assessment and includes an explanation of the community served by the hospital. Hospitals must solicit feedback on the plan from the community through annual presentations and submit a publicly available report detailing who attended the meeting and what was discussed. The legislation also requires the Department of Health Care Policy and Financing to include a summary of estimated federal and state tax exemptions made by each hospital in its annual report. The Department must also establish a minimum annual community investment target, and the bill allows the department to take remedial action procedures for hospitals that fail to meet the minimum community investment threshold.
sponsor: Rep. Judy Amabile (D) and Rep. Dominick Moreno (D)

summary: As part of a larger public health bill, this measure shifts oversight of existing community benefit law from the Office of the Healthcare Advocate (OHA) to the Office of Health Strategy (OHS). It would require hospitals to regularly submit their community health needs assessments, related implementation strategies, and community benefit status reports, including several specified reporting requirements. It requires for-profit acute care hospitals to submit community benefit program reporting consistent with the bill’s reporting schedules and reasonably similar to what they would report to the IRS, where applicable. It requires OHS to make data from the state’s all-payer claims database available to hospitals for the purposes of fulfilling these requirements; and it would require OHS to annually summarize and analyze community benefit program reporting data and solicit stakeholder input through a public comment period. Lastly, the measure removes managed care organizations from the requirements of community benefit law.

This measure requires non-profit hospitals to provide the state and public with an annual report outlining their community benefits spending. The bill defines “community benefits program,” outlines the minimum contents that must be included in a community benefits activity report, and requires that the report be made available to the public. The bill contains provisions allowing the report to be submitted electronically to state officials on an annual basis. The deadline for submitting the report is 30 days after a hospital files a federal Form 990. The bill also contains technical changes to reference and accord with appropriate law and regulations, and broadens the list of information that must be included in the community benefits report.
sponsor: Rep. Paul Baumbach (D), Sen. Marie Pinkney (D)

summary: This measure establishes for certain hospitals, certain property is exempt from taxation, including: real property and personal property including medical equipment. Establishes in order to receive a property tax exemption, a nonprofit hospital must: 1) provide documentation showing it is organized as a nonprofit per Idaho code, 2) provide documentation showing it has received an exemption from the IRS pursuant to 501(c)(3) of the internal revenue code, 3) provide a copy of its internal revenue service form 990 schedule h, and 4) for hospitals not designated by CMS as a critical access hospital: a) copy of the most recent community health needs assessment and implementation strategy, b) copy its written financial assistance policy (FAP) and emergency medical care policy, c) limit the amount charged for emergency or other medically necessary care under the FAP, d) make reasonable efforts to determine if an individual is eligible for the FAP before engaging in extraordinary collection actions, and e) provide a general public benefit to the county is is located as measured by its annual community benefit report filed with the board of equalization. Establishes if a nonprofit hospital uses property for business from which revenue is derived that is not directly related to exempt purposes, then the property be assessed and taxed as any other property. If property is used in part, then the assessor determine the value of the part used that is not related to exempt purposes, with an exemption if 3% or less. Requires nonprofit hospitals issued property tax exemption and operating 150 or more beds prepare a community benefits report and file with the board of equalization by December 31 of each year. Requires the report include audited information, and certain information itemized.

Aims to advance health equity by lowering hospital costs for low-income and uninsured residents and increasing transparency of community benefit plan information. It makes several changes to community benefit reporting requirements including requiring non-profit hospital community benefit plans to describe activities the hospital is undertaking to address health equity, reduce health disparities, and improve community health; and requiring health systems to report charity care spending and financial assistance application data separately for each individual hospital. It also adds definitions for charity care and bed debt. The measure also requires hospitals submit their plans to the Attorney General, who will post it online and send a copy to the Governor and General Assembly. The plan must include charity care costs, total net patient revenue, total community benefits spending, and information on financial assistance applications, including submission and demographic (i.e., race, ethnicity, sex, and language) data. It provides a late filing fee for nonprofit hospitals for community benefits plans of $2,500 per month that the report is late (rather than $100).

This measure directs the Health Service Cost Review Commission to establish the Community Benefit Reporting Workgroup composed of individuals and stakeholders with knowledge of, and impacted by, hospital community benefit spending. Nonprofit hospitals will be required to submit an annual report on community benefit spending. The commission, in consultation with non-profit hospital representatives, will adopt regulations which establish the standard reporting format, the reporting deadline, and the period of time the report must cover. The workgroup’s recommendations, to be adopted into regulations by the commission, will include a requirement that hospitals submit an annual report to the commission detailing the community benefits provided by the hospital during the preceding year, including: hospital activities to address identified community health needs, the cost of each activity, and a list of tax exemptions the hospital claimed, among other details. The commission will establish a method through which state and local governing bodies are made aware of the meetings of the Community Benefit Reporting Workgroup. Additionally, the commission will compile these reports into a publicly available Nonprofit Hospital Community Health Benefit Report which will be submitted to the House Health and Government Operations and Senate Finance committees.

Establishes and funds coordinated community supports partnerships across education, health, and other stakeholders to meet students’ behavioral health needs and provide community services and supports to students. It allows a non-profit hospital that receives funding for coordinating or participating in a partnership to include the value of the services provided as part of its community benefit spending.
sponsor: Sen. Guy Guzzone (D) and Sen. Katie Hester (D)

summary: This measure includes a provision that prohibits a hospital from considering a household's monetary assets in determining eligibility for free and reduced-cost care under the hospital's financial assistance policy.
sponsor: Del. Lesley Lopez (D), Del. Deni Taveras (D), Del. Nick Allen (D), Del. Adrian Boafo (D), Del. Lorig Charkoudian (D), Del. Bonnie Cullison (D), Del. Julie Palakovich Carr (D), Del. Emily Shetty (D)

summary: This measure amends the criteria for a financial assistance policy, income thresholds and patient's out-of-pocket expenses, and notice requirements. Prohibits a hospital from reporting adverse information to a consumer reporting agency, and filing a civil action to collect medical debt at or below $500. Prohibits for eligible patients a hospital charging interest on medical debt, and collecting a fee or any other amount that exceeds the approved charge. Requires a hospital refund a patient that is eligible for free care. Amends guidelines for payment amounts. Establishes a civil action at law be filed within 3 years from the data it accrues with exceptions, and 12 years after certain actions accrues or date of death of the principal debtor or creditor.
sponsor: Sen. Stephen S Hershey, Jr (R), Del. Lorig Charkoudian (D)

summary: This measure updates the definition of community benefit to include a community health worker workforce program, and include a partnership between a nonprofit hospital and a community-based organization to establish a community health worker workforce program. Establishes the primary purpose of a community health worker workforce program, and the criteria required for the partnership between a nonprofit hospital and a community-based organization.
sponsor: Del. Heather Bagnall (D), Del. Bonnie Cullison (D), Del. Terri L Hill (D), Del. Joseline A Pena-Melnyk (D)

summary: This measure requires hospitals investigate the coverage of, and if appropriate provide free health care services (charity care) to patients whose family income is equal to, or less than 200% of the federal poverty level. Establishes certain requirements applying to a hospitals' financial assistance program, and to charity care. Requires hospitals widely publicize its financial assistance programs within the community served, and requires certain actions be taken in the notice and publication of the program. Requires hospitals provide patients with written notice of the availability of charity care, which must meet certain requirements and contain certain information. Requires hospitals inform an eligible patient if any services is not covered by the hospitals' financial assistance programs. Prohibits a hospital from billing a patient for services if it failed to provide advance notice if a service is not covered under the financial assistance program. Establishes a hospital may bill a patient's health insurance carrier for a service for which the hospital is prohibited from billing the patient. Requires hospitals offer a patient with family income not exceeding 400% of the federal poverty level a payment plan that requires monthly out-of-pocket payments not to exceed 3% of the patient's monthly family income that is not exempt from attachment or garnishment under state law. Requires a billing statement include how to dispute a charge and certain information be included if appropriate. Requires hospitals provide an online option to apply for charity care. Establishes certain requirements of the online option. Requires the department establish a process for patient complaints of noncompliance with this measure, conduct a review of complaints within a certain amount of time, and require a corrective action of a hospital if found noncompliant. Establishes violations for noncompliance. Requires the department develop an application for patients to apply for financial assistance programs including charity care, and must meet certain requirements. Establishes the department establish rules for these provisions.

This measure requires each nonprofit hospital report its community benefit spending to the department of public health and human services in a manner provided by the department. Requires the report include certain information, including how the expenses related to the needs identified in the community health needs assessment. Requires each nonprofit hospital provide a total annual community benefit expense that exceeds the property tax liability, defines how this is calculated, and establishes reporting requirements. Establishes an account to credit the department of public health and human services to support critical access health care base funding, which will be funded by nonprofit tax liability fees. Requires the department of revenue prepare and provide the department of public health and human services with a statement of potential tax liability. Establishes potential tax liability considerations, prohibitions, and requirements when considering nonprofit hospitals. Defines community benefit and potential tax liability.

This appropriation requires every general hospital to file the IRS Form 990 with the State by July 1 of each calendar year. Requires hospitals submit the information used to complete the IRS Form 990 in the manner prescribed by the department, including certain information related to community benefit expense. Requires the department compile information reported annually by October 1, 2026, and delivered to the governor, and general assembly. Requires the report include certain information.

Requires every hospital to make reasonable efforts to screen every uninsured patient to determine whether the individual is eligible for Medicaid or hospital financial assistance, and to inform every financial assistance-eligible, uninsured patient of the option to enter a payment plan with the hospital, with payments based upon the patient's ability to pay. It requires every hospital to annually report the amount of charity care, discounted care, or other financial assistance provided by the hospital under its financial assistance policy and the amount of uncollected bad debt, including any uncollected bad debt from payment plans. The State Health Commissioner is required to report this collected data annually to the legislature by November 1. The measure requires hospitals receiving federal financial assistance to make written information about the hospital's charity care policies available to persons with limited English proficiency in accordance with the most recent U.S. Department of Health and Human Services' Guidance. It also prohibits hospitals from engaging in certain actions to recover medical debt.

This measure aims to make hospital operations more transparent, and it includes a requirement that non-profit hospitals identify community health improvement activities that cost $5,000 or more and that designated critical access or sole community hospitals report information for the 10 highest cost community health improvement activities. These activities are reported through an addendum to their CHNA starting July 1, 2022. Additionally, the law requires that hospitals report demographic data about the people involved with the CHNA process and requires that hospitals include specified groups: community organizations that provide community health improvement services; communities impacted by health inequities; health care workers; hospitals; and the governor’s interagency coordinating council on health disparities.

This measure requires hospitals to develop, implement, and maintain a policy to enable indigent persons access to charity care. Policies must include identifying patients who may be eligible for coverage through Medicaid or the state’s health benefits exchange. It requires that all hospitals include full charity care for patients with income up to 200 percent of the federal poverty level (FPL), 75 percent discount for patients with incomes between 201 and 250 percent FPL, and 50 percent discount for patients with income between 251 and 300 percent FPL. It establishes higher income thresholds for hospitals of a certain bed size or owned or operated by a health system (e.g., full charity care for patients with income up to 300 percent FPL).

This measure amends Section 127501 of the Health and Safety Code, and establishes requirements and duties of the Office of Health Care Affordability within the Department of Health Care Access and Information. Requires the office: 1) Increase cost transparency through public reporting 2) Support the board in establishing a statewise health care cost target for health care spending 3) Support the board to establish specific health care cost targets by health care sector 4) Collect and analyze data to track spending, set cost targets, approve performance improvement plans, monitor healthcare workforce, and carry out other functions 5) Analyze cost and quality trends for drugs with consideration to other reports required under statute 6) Oversee progress towards meeting the health care cost target through certain actions 7) Promote, measure, and publicly report performance on quality and health equity 8) Advance standards for promoting the adoption of alternative payment models 9) Measure and promote sustained systemwide investment in primary care and behavioral health 10) Advance standards for health care workforce stability and training 11) Disssemnate best practices from entites that comply with the cost target 12) Review and evaluate consolidation, market power, and other market failsures through cost and market impact reviews of mergers, acquisitions, or corporate affiliations involving other health care entities 13) Analyze trends in the price of health care technologies 14) Analyse trends in the cost of labor 15) Conduct research and evaluation on payers, fully integrated delivery systems, management services organizations, and providers and how they impact cost, quality, equity, and workforce stability 16) Adopt and promulgate regulations 17) Establish advisory or technical committees Requires the office establish requirements for managment services organizations (MSOs) to submit data and other information as necessary. Requires the office monitor cost trends, including on the health care market including but not limited to consolidation, market power, venture capital activity, profit margins, and other market failures. Requires the office examine mergers, acquisitions, corporate affiliations, or other material change transactions to ownership, operations, or governance structure involving certain health care entities. Requires the office prospectively analyze those transactions likely to have significant effects, seek input from the parties and public, and report on anticipated impacts. Establishes exempted providers, and requirements of an entity not an exempted provider to the office: 1) Provide written notice of agreements or transactions that include but are not limited to selling of transferring control 2) Requires written notice of agreements or transactions between the noticing entity and a healthcare entity or management services organization, or an entity that owns or controls the MSO 3) Requires MSOs provide written notice of any agreement or transaction meets criteria between the MSO and another entity 4) Requires the office adopt regulations 5) Requires written notice be provided at least 90 days prior to entering into an agreement or transaction, and office should make the notice of material change public if certain criteria are met 6) Establishes the requirements to provide notice of a material change does not apply to certain entities, agreements, or transactions 7) Defines a noticing entity includes: private equity group, hedge funds, a newly created business for the purpose of entering into agreements or transactions with a health care entity, a MSO, and an entity that owns, operates, or controls a provider

This measure updates the definitions of "hedge fund" and "private equity group." Prohibits a private equity group or hedge fund from: 1) interfering with the professional judgement of physicians or dentists in making health care decisions, or 2) exercising control over, or delegating the power to do certain activities. Prohibits a private equity group or hedge fund, or an entity they control directly or indirectly from entering into a contract or other agreement with a physician or dental practice doing business in the state if the deal would interfere with the professional judgement of the physician or dentist, or exercise control over or delegate powers over certain activities. Establishes any provision within a contract or other agreement violating these provisions is void, unenforceable, and against public policy. Establishes any contract involving the management of a physician or dental practice, or the sale of real estate or other assets owned by a physician or dental practice, a private equity group or hedge fund, or any entity controlled directly or indirectly by private equity or hedge fund, cannot include any clause barring any provider in that practice from: 1) competing with the practice in the event of a termination or resignation, 2) disparaging, opining, or commenting on that practice. Establishes any provision of a contract violating these terms is void, unenforceable, and against public policy. Establishes exceptions. Establishes the Attorney General be entitled to injunctive relief and other equitable remedies as a court deems appropriate. Notes the intention of this section is to ensure clinical decision making and treatment decisions are exclusively in the hands of licensed health care providers. Establishes the section does not narrow, abrogate, or lower the bar on the corporate practice of medicine or dentistry. Establishes this does not prohibit an unlicensed person or entity from assisting, or consulting with a physician or dental practice as long as the licensee retains the ultimate responsibility and approval for decisions and activities.

This measure enacts the Colorado State Antitrust Act of 2023. This measure prohibits monopolization, mergers, and acquisitions that may lessen competition or tend or create a monopoly. This measure establishes that nothing in this article prohibits or shall be construed to prohibit the formation and operation of health care coverage cooperatives or provider networks. This measure empowers the state Attorney General to, if they have reasonable cause to believe that any person has engaged in or is engaging in behavior that violates this measure or federal antitrust statutes, request the person to file a statement or report in writing about the potential violation, issue subpoenas, and conduct investigative hearings. The Attorney General may bring a civil action on behalf of the state, any governmental or public entity, and any individual injured, either directly or indirectly, in its business or property by reason of any violation of this article and, if successful, shall recover any actual damanges sustained by the entity. The court, upon finding a violation of this article, shall impose a civil penalty to be paid to the general fund of the state in an amount not to exceed one million dollars for each such violation. This measure establishes the statute of limitations for any civil action commenced under this article to be four years.
sponsor: Rep. Mike Weissman, Sen. Julie Gonzales, Sen. Robert Rodriguez

summary: This measure voids a covenant not to compete that restricts the right of an individual to receive compensation for performance of labor. Excludes from the highly compensated worker exemption a covenant not to compete that restricts the practice of medicine, practice of advanced practice registered nursing, and the practice of dentistry. Establishes non solicitation covenants are excluded from the highly compensated worker exemption that restricts the practice of medicine, the practice of advanced practice registered nursing, or the practice of dentistry. Establishes an exemption for a covenant not to compete when a minority owner receives equity compensation depending on an established calculation provided in the measure, and when a reasonable confidentiality provision or trade secret meets certain criteria. Prohibits a covenant restricting the practice of medicine, practice of advanced practice registered nursing, or the practice of dentistry if the covenant prohibits or materially restrict a provider from disclosing to a patient certain information regarding the providers departure from the practice.
sponsor: Sen. Lindsey Daugherty (D), Sen. Lisa Frizell (R), Rep. Kyle Brown (D), Rep. Lori Garcia Sander (R)

summary: This measure requires a person meeting certain criteria and who is filing a pre-merger notification with the federal government, file a copy of the Hart-Scott-Rodino form with the Colorado Attorney General. Establishes confidentiality and penalties.
sponsor: Sen. Marc Snyder (D), Rep. Cecilia Espenoza (D)

summary: This measure prohibits all-or-nothing clauses, anti-steering clauses, anti-tiering clauses, gag clauses, and most-favored nation health carrier or health plan administrator clauses in contracts between health carriers and health care providers. The law includes provisions requiring disclosure to providers on how health carriers select providers for and evaluate providers in tiering arrangements. These provisions are effective July 1, 2024. Note: This is a larger bill that contains several provisions. Other provisions are included in the appropriate tab.
sponsor: Rep. Robyn Porter (D), Rep. Eleni Kavros DeGraw (D), and Rep. Tammy Nuccio (R)

summary: This measure establishes a covered garden leave agreement and a covered non compete agreement do not violate public policy as a restraint on trade or an attempt to monopolize trade or commerce in the state, provided certain criteria are met. Establishes a review period by an employee, and caps a the agreement to 4 years. Establishes remedies for a breach of these agreement types. Establishes a notice process and requirements, and a breach of the agreement and remedies for that breach.

This measure specifies that the state employee health plan statute does not prohibit the state personnel department from directly contracting with health care providers for health care services for state employees, and requires a hospital to post pricing information in compliance with the federal Hospital Price Transparency Rule of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services if the federal Hospital Price Transparency Rule is repealed or federal enforcement of the rule is stopped. Additionally, the bill changes the date that ambulatory outpatient surgical centers are required to begin posting certain pricing information from March 31, 2021, to Dec. 31, 2021, and specifies that if an ambulatory outpatient surgical center offers less than 30 additional services, the center is required to post all of the services the center provides. The measure had language stripped out in committee relating to hospital consolidation. The removed language would have required the attorney general to review mergers, acquisitions, and other transactions concerning hospitals, hospital systems, and investors of hedge funds and public equity funds, authorized the attorney general to approve or deny the merger, acquisition, or transaction, and allowed for a waiver under certain circumstances.

This measure defines "merger" and "merger agreeement" for the purposes of the certificate of public advantage (COPA) for certain hospital mergers. The Department of Health (IDOH) would be required to actively supervise a merger. Additionally, IDOH would be allowed to enter into an agreement with a nonprofit organization or a postsecondary educational institution to study the impacts of the COPA on the community's health metrics and outcomes.
sponsor: Sen. Ed Charbonneau (R), Sen. Jon Ford (R), and Sen. Alan Morrison (R)

summary: This measure requires health care entities to provide notice of certain mergers or acquisitions with a value of at least $10 million to specified members of the general assembly. Notice must be submitted at least six months prior to the transaction date. As of 1/29/2024, this measure has been amended to require health care entities to provide written notice of certain mergers or acquisitions with a value of at least $10 million, at least 90 days prior to the date of the transaction, to the office of the attorney general. The bill specifies notice requirements and requires the office of the attorney general to review the information submitted with the notice. The office of the attorney general may analyze in writing any antitrust concerns with the transaction and issue a civil investigative demand for additional information. In addition, the definition of "health care entity" includes private equity partnerships seeking to enter into a merger or acquisition with defined entities.
sponsor: Sen. Chris Garten (R), Sen. Ed Charbonneau (R), Sen. Liz Brown (R), Sen. Justin Busch (R), Sen. Tyler Johnson (R), Sen. Gary Byrne (R), Sen. Stacey Donato (R), Sen. J.D. Ford (D), Rep. Donna Schaibley (R), Rep. Brad Barrett (R), Rep. Julie McGuire (R)

summary: This measure prohibits an application for a certificate of public advantage (COPA) after a certain date. Establishes the items required for a COPA application, the requirements of the application, and the requirements of the parties and state as part of the application process. Establishes the time frame in which the attorney general and department of health has to review and make a determination as both a timeframe and end date for any review.
sponsor: Sen. Ed Charbonneau (R), Sen. Tyler Johnson (R), Rep. Brad Barrett (R), Rep. Robert Heaton (R)

summary: This measure requires the state department to cooperate with the secretary of state and the department of insurance to develop and implement a plan to collect certain hospital information, including ownership information. Requires the state department publish on its website a report with the collected information, and provide the information collected to the legislative council, the office of the attorney general, and the health care cost oversight task force. Updates the definition of "health care entity." Requires each health care entity report certain ownership information to the state department. Requires the secretary of state cooperate with the Indiana department of health, and department of insurance to develop and implement a plan to collect the information. Establishes the office of the attorney general at any time may investigate the market concentration of a health care entity, and issue a civil investigative demand to a healthcare entity. Requires on July 1, 2025 and then annually, each insurer, third party administrator, and pharmacy benefit manager file wit the department a report that includes certain ownership information. Requires the department cooperate with the Indiana department of health and secretary of state to develop and implement a plan to collect the information. Requires before September 1 each year, the department provide the information collected to the department of health. Establishes the department of health may assess a fine on an insurer, third party administrator, or pharmacy benefit manager for violation of this measure. Requires before December 1 of each year, the department submit to the legislative council an annual report with the: 1) violations assessed, and 2) fines waived. Establishes reporting requirement notifications to insurers, third party administrators, and pharmacy benefit managers.
sponsor: Rep. Julie McGuire (R), Rep. Ben Smaltz (R), Sen. Johnson Garten, Sen. Ed Charboneau

summary: This measure establishes after July 1, 2025, a physician and a hospital, parent company of a hospital, or affiliated manager of a hospital or health system may not enter into a noncompete agreement.
sponsor: Sen. Justin Busch (R), Sen. Ed Charbonneau (R), Sen. Tyler Johnson (R)

summary: The bill makes important updates to the oversight of hospital systems and provider organizations, including: 1) bolstering the reporting authority of the Center for Health Analysis and Information (CHIA) and scope of the oversight of the Health Policy Commission (HPC)), including significant equity investors; 2) audited financial statement reporting is mandated for out-of-state operators of a hospital or RPO parent company, private equity investors, and management services organizations (MSOs); 3) enhancing penalties for not complying with CHIA data reporting requirements, including increasing and removing the cap on financial penalties; 4) requiring CHIA to notify HPC and the Department of Public Health (DPH) of failure to report, which will be considered during a review by the HPC in the Cost and Market Impact Review (CMIR) process and by DPH when considering a Determination of Need (DON) application or when reviewing licensure and suitability. 5) expanding DPH authority over the Board of Registration in Medicine to improve oversight and align Board activities with broader state market oversight goals; 6) requiring DPH to hold a public hearing prior to hospital and essential service closures, and authorizing DPH to seek an impact analysis of a hospital closure of any essential health service from HPC.
sponsor: Rep. John J. Lawn, Jr. (D), Sen. Cindy F. Friedman (D)

summary: This measure includes a provision that directs the Maryland Health Care Commission to contract with a private consultant to study the effect of private equity firms on the health care market in the state, including: the impact on the state's ability to meet goals and objectives of the Total Cost of Care model and the impact on efforts to address health disparities and social determinants of health. The commission must also study the payer mix for physician practices and groups with private equity ownership, the impact of hospital consolidations on physician practices, the acquisition on physician practices, and the impact on the ability of non-profit hospitals and health systems to maintain access to care, including the ability to hire and retain physicians. The commission must report on the findings and recommendations from the study to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Health and Government Operations Committee by January 1, 2025.
sponsor: Del. Terri Hill (D), Del. H.B. Bhandari (D), Del. Brian Chisholm (R) et al. / Sen. J. B. Jennings (R)

summary: This measure prohibits a private equity company or real estate investment trust from acquiring or increasing a direct or indirect ownership interest, or operational control, or financial control in a hospital in the state. Establishes a moratorium.

This measure requires notice to the state of all transactions where the health care entity involved has average annual revenue of at least $80 million or the transaction will result in an entity projected to have an average annual revenue of at least $80 million once operating at full capacity. This measure defines "health care entity" as a hospital, hospital system, captive professional entity, medical foundation, provider group practice, an entity organized or controlled by any of the aforementioned entities, or an entity that owns or exercises control over any of the aforementioned entities. A health care entity must provide notice to the attorney general and the commissioner of health at least 60 days before the proposed completion date of the transaction and disclose in the notice information about the ownership, services provided, revenue, and locations of each entity, as well as about the terms of the transaction agreements, all considerations relevant to the transaction, markets in which the entities expect postmerger synergies to produce a competitive advantage, potential areas of expansion, any planned closures, how staffing will change as a result of the transaction, and any other information relevant to the transaction as requested by the attorney general or the commissioner. The health care entity must also submit the transaction agreements, any projections, modelings, or reports relevant to the transaction, and each entity's audited and unaudited financial statements from the previous five years. Any nonprofit entity must submit a certification sworn under oath by each board member and chief executive officer that the completed transaction would in the public interest and disclosing each declarant's compensation and benefits related to the transaction for the subsequent three years, as well as any conflicts of interest. This measure also stipulates additional requirements for nonprofit health care entities to consider their charitable trust, public benefit assets, and fiduciary duty. The attorney general may bring an action to district court to enjoin or unwind a transaction or seek other equitable relief necessary to protect the public interest if a health care entity or transaction violates this section and/or if the transaction is contrary to public interest. The commissioner may provide data, research, and insight to the attorney general to use when evaluating whether a transaction is contrary to public interest. This measure also forbids any transaction that will substantially lessen competition or tend to create a monopoly or monopsony. This measure also requires any health care entity involved in a transaction that has an average annual revenue between $10 million and $80 million or for which the transaction will result in average annual revenue between $10 million and $80 million, to provide data on the transaction to the commissioner at least 30 days before the proposed date of transaction completion. The data shall include information on the entities involved and their ownership structure, the services offered by each and their locations, the terms of the transaction, any plans to expand or close services, staffing changes, and any other information requested by the commissioner. The commissioner shall use data collected under this section to analyze the number of health care transactions in Minnesota and the potential impact these transactions may have on equitable access to or the cost and quality of health care services, and develop recommendations for the legislature on improvements to the law. This measure forbids the University of Minnesota health care facilities to be owned or controlled by a for-profit or out-of-state entity unless the attorney general deems it to be in the public interest. This measure directs the commissioner of health to study and develop recommendations on the regulation of conversions, mergers, transfers of assets, and other transactions affecting nonprofit health maintenance organizations and for-profit health maintenance organizations.
sponsor: Rep. Robert Bierman (DFL), Rep. Tina Liebling (DFL), Rep. Zack Stephenson (DFL), Rep. Mohamud Noor (DFL)

summary: This is the state fiscal appropriations bill. This measure requires notice to the state of any conversion transaction involving a nonprofit health coverage entity. This measure defines "nonprofit health coverage entity" as a domestic nonprofit health service plan corporation or domestic nonprofit health maintenance organization. The health coverage entity must ensure that the proposed transaction does not constitute a breach of charitable trust or fiduciary duty, the entity shall receive full and fair value for its public benefit assets, and the transaction shall promote the public benefit. A nonprofit coverage entity may not enter into a conversion transaction until 60 days after the entity has given written notice. A nonprofit health coverage entity may not convert, transfer, or sell assets if the transaction would result in the use of the assets conflicting with their restricted purpose. The attorney general may bring an action to district court to enjoin or unwind a transaction or seek other equitable relief necessary to protect the public interest if a health care entity or transaction violates this section and/or if the transaction is contrary to public interest. The commissioner may provide data, research, and insight to the attorney general to use when evaluating whether a transaction is contrary to public interest. This measure all directs the commissioner of health to conduct and publish public reports on the aggregate impact of transactions within nonprofit health coverage entities on access to or the cost of health care service, health care market consolidation, and health care quality. This measure appropriates $53,000 in fiscal year 2025 to the attorney general for the review and related investigatory and enforcement actions for nonprofit health coverage entity conversion transactions.
sponsor: Rep. Aisha Gomez (DFL), Rep. Carlie Kotyza-Witthuhn (DFL), Rep. Nolan West (R)

summary: This measure provides immunity from liability under antitrust or competition laws to community hospitals consolidating or collaborating with another public, private, or nonprofit hospital; healthcare facility; or provider, effective March 30, 2023.

This measure enacts the Health Care Consolidation Oversight Act, requiring review of proposed health care mergers, acquisitions and other material changes in control of health care entities, including insurers. Proposed transactions that involve an existing health care entity or the creation of a health care entity in New Mexico and at least one party with average annual revenue of $20 million or more in the immediately preceding three years or, for a new entity, is projected to $10 million in average annual revenue over the first three years of operation are subject to review. The Office of Superintendent of Insurance and the Health Care Authority are directed to review proposed transactions. The Office may approve, conditionally approve, or disapprove transactions. The bill also provides post-transaction oversight and prescribes a criminal penalty for false information. As of 2/5/2024, this measure has been amended to require notice and review of only proposed transactions involving hospitals that constitute mergers, acquisitions and other changes in control of hospitals.
