The bill requires that acquiring entities annually submit reports to the Office for three years after approval or conditional approval.
sponsor: Sen. Katy Duhigg (D), Sen. Liz Stefanics (D)

summary: This measure updates and adds several definitions, establishes oversight power of the health care authority applies to proposed transactions, replacing the office of the superintendent of insurance. Establishes confidentiality requirements. Requires a notice of a proposed transaction be deemed complete by the authority on the date when all the information required is submitted, and within 30 days the authority notify the parties if the notice complete or not. Swaps the responsibilities of the office to the authority for proposed transactions. Adds and amends items required in a proposed transaction notification to the authority. Establishes the authority may retain certain subject matter experts as necessary to assist in conducting the review. Requires the authority provide all notices and documents to the office and attorney general. Establishes the attorney general may provide input to the authority about the proposed transaction relative to the Antitrust Act, the Unfair Practices Act, or other state or federal law. When conducting a review of a proposed transaction, adds that the authority may consider current and future wages, benefits, working conditions, employment protections and restrictions and other terms and conditions of employment. Establishes after control is acquired of a hospital or independent health care practice, reports are due to the authority and office annually for three years after approval or conditional approval. Establishes conditions to an approval remain in effect for no longer than 3 years from the conditional approval. Requires the authority enforce the provisions of the measure, transactions shall not be effectuated without the secretary's written determination that no review is needed, or is approved with or without conditions. Establishes violations and penalties, and requires money collected from fines associated with this measure be deposited to the state treasury to credit the current school fund. Establishes nothing in the measure limits the authority of the attorney general. Establishes New Mexico courts have personal jurisdiction over the parties to a transaction subject to this measure, including the parties to the transaction and any person affiliated with a party. Prohibits an entity from taking any retaliatory action against a whistleblower who meets certain criteria. Requires every entity adopt, promulgate, and enforce a whistleblower protection policy that meets certain requirements. Establishes the secretary may assess an administrative fine for findings of retaliatory action, and establishes notification requirements. Requires the authority post hospital ownership annually to the authority's website and at any point in a change in ownership.
sponsor: Rep. Reena Szczepanski (D), Rep. Christine Chandler (D), Sen. Katy Duhigg (D)

summary: This measure prohibits insurers from entering into contracts with most-favored-nation clauses and anti-disclosure clauses. The bill had language stripped out that would have explicitly prohibited all-or-nothing clauses, anti-tiering/steering clauses, and exclusive contracting clauses.

This measure, effective March 3, 2023, expands the prohibition on most-favored-nations provisions and non-disclosure agreements to corporations and group health plan contracts. The bill also extends the effective date of a bill passed during the previous legislative session that prohibited insurers from entering into contracts with such provisions from January 1, 2023 until July 1, 2023.
sponsor: Asm. Catalina Cruz (D) / Sen. Andrew Gounardes (D)

summary: This measure reqiuires certain health care entities to provide 30 days’ pre-closing notice to the New York State Department of Health in connection with material transactions that have revenue thresholds of $25 million or more. This provision is effective ninety days after May 3, 2023. Note: This is a larger bill that contains several provisions. Other provisions are included in the appropriate tab.

This measure includes a provision that extends the date through which arrangements may be approved under state action immunity. The Commissioner of Health may approve arrangements among health care providers for which state action immunity under the state and federal antitrust laws is needed through December 31, 2028. As of 2/20/2024, this measure has been amended to make changes unrelated to the antitrust provision.
sponsor: Joint 2016 General Budget Conference Committee / Senate Budget and Revenue Committee

summary: This measure authorizes the Oregon Health Authority (OHA) to review health care mergers, acquisitions, or affiliations to ensure they maintain access to affordable health care. Transactions that meet the threshold for review occur when at least one party had average revenue of $25 million or more in the preceding three fiscal years, and the other party had average revenue of at least $10 million in the preceding three fiscal years. OHA can impose a civil penalty for violation, not to exceed $10,000 for each offense, or $1,000 for each offense by an individual healthcare professional. The operative date for OHA’s authority to begin reviewing these transactions is March 1st, 2022. OHA is also directed to commission studies of the impact of consolidation in the state every 4 years. The original language required approval of mergers, acquisitions, or affiliations of entities that had $25 million or more in net patient revenue in prior fiscal year or before mergers, acquisitions or affiliations that will result in one entity having increase in net patient revenue of $1 million or more. The bill also directs the Oregon Health Policy Board to establish criteria for approval of mergers, acquisitions and affiliations.

This measure prohibits a management service organization (MSO) from owning, controlling, exercising proxy power, pay dividends from shares, acquire or finance the acquisition of the majority of shares of a medical entity, exercise control over clinical operations or clinical decision making, or participate in terms of employment of a medical entity. Establishes the criteria when a MSO owns, controls, manages, directs, or participates in managing a medical entity. Establishes the conditions a medical entity may restrict a sale of the entity's stock, interest, or assets. Establishes the criteria for an individual who provides medical or health care services for a medical entity, and the criteria for these measures prohibitions not to apply. Prohibits with exceptions a professional corporation providing in the articles of incorporation, bylaws, contract, or other agreement or arrangement removing a director or officer meeting certain criteria from their position. Establishes a professional corporation may relinquish or transfer control over the administration, business, or clinical operations only if it meets criteria and is for the benefit of a majority of shareholders who are licensed physicians in the state. Establishes officers of a professional corporation with exceptions must ben licensees. Establishes in a professional corporation, a naturopathic physician must meet certain ownership and control criteria. Prohibits with exceptions a professional corporation from directing or controlling the professional judgement of a naturopathic physician. Establishes the criteria a noncompetition agreement, nondisclosure agreement, non disparagement agreement between certain parties and under certain conditions is valid and enforceable. Prohibits a MSO or medical entity from taking disciplinary action against a licensee under certain circumstances.
sponsor: Sen. Deb Patterson (D), Rep. Ben Bowman (D), Rep. Cyrus Javadi (R), Rep. Kevin Mannix (R)

summary: This measure requires the transacting parties and the new hospital seeking conversion to supply additional information in their application for review by the Department of Health and the Department of the Attorney General relating to staffing levels, pension plans and impact for the affected communities before and after the proposed conversion.

This measure prohibits providers from offering, entering into, or renewing a provider network contract that includes an anti-steering, anti-tiering, gag, or most favored nation clauses, effective June 12, 2023.
sponsor: Rep. James Frank (R), Rep. Sam Harless (R), Rep. Greg Bonnen (R)

summary: This measure prohibits an employer from entering into, enforcing, or threatening to enforce a covenant not to compete with any low-wage employee except under certain circumstances.
This measure enacts a uniform antitrust premerger notification with the attorney general.
sponsor: Sen. Yasmin Trudeau (D), Sen. Jamie Pedersen (D)

summary: This measure requires any registering entity (parent company, holding company, or controls or owns more than one health care entity or any affiliates or subsidiaries) to annually report to the department of health certain information including ownership. Establishes the department may share and receive information relevant to this measure. Requires the department make the data submitted for this measure publicly available and updated annually. Establishes the department may audit and inspect records of any registering entity and its affiliates and subsidiaries that have failed to submit complete information. Establishes penalties for noncompliance. Requires the department in consultation with the health care authority and office of the insurance commissioner develop a plan and provide recommendations on how the reporting requirements in this measure apply to certain professions and entities.
sponsor: Rep. Dan Bronoske (D), Rep. Mary Fosse (D), Sen. Annette M Cleveland (D), Sen. Robert Hasegawa (D)

summary: This measure voids any covenant not to compete that restricts the right of any person to receive compensation for performance of labor, with exceptions. Voids any covenant not to compete in an employment, partnership, or corporate agreement between physicians that restricts the right of a physician to practice medicine upon termination of employment, partnership, or corporate affiliation. Establishes a physician may disclose their continuing practice of medicine and contact information to any patient with a rare disorder.

This measure requires the Director of Public Health to establish a statewide health care cost target for total and per capita health care expenditures by 2024 and specific targets by health care sector, including fully integrated delivery system sector, geographic region, or other category of individual health care entity by 2027. This bill also establishes the Office of Health Care Affordability to set standards for various health care metrics, to analyze the health care market for cost trends and drivers of spending, develop data-informed policies for lowering health care costs for consumers, set and enforce a statewide health care cost target for total health care expenditures and specific targets by health care sector and geographic region, and create a state strategy for controlling the cost of health care and ensuring affordability for consumers and purchasers. The office is required to take progressive actions against health care entities for failing to meet the cost targets, including corrective action plans and escalating administrative penalties. The bill also establishes an 11-member Health Care Affordability Advisory Board to recommend health care cost targets and to make recommendations to the Director of Statewide Health Planning and Development and the office.

This measure directs the Office of Health Strategy (OHS) to set the annual cost growth benchmarks and primary care spending targets, to develop and adopt quality benchmarks, to develop strategies to meet such benchmarks, and to monitor performance against the benchmark. The executive director shall publish the cost growth benchmark and annual primary care spending targets as a percentage of total medical expenses for calendar years 2021 to 2025, as well as the annual quality benchmarks for 2022 to 2025, on the website. The executive director to meet with a payer or provider entity to review their submitted total medical expense data upon request, and to identify any payer or provider that exceeded the cost growth benchmark or failed to meet the primary care spending target for the performance year. The executive director shall hold an annual public hearing, beginning 2023, to compare the grwoth in total health care expenditures in the performance year to the health care cost growth benchmark. The executive director may require any payer or proivder entity found to be a significant contributor to cost growth in the state to participate in such hearing. This measure also directs the executive director to develop and adopt annual cost growth benchmarks and primary care spending targets for the following five calendar years for provider entities and payers beginning in 2025.
sponsor: Rep. Matthew Ritter / Sen. Martin Looney

summary: This measure creates the Diamond State Hospital Cost Review Board, and establishes the Board's purpose is to carry out hospital budget reviews and other related functions. Establishes which stakeholders will determine Board composition and term length, the required qualifications, compensation, process promulgating rules and regulations, and the operating process of the Board. Establishes four actions require an affirmative vote of the majority of the Board: 1) approval of hospital budget, 2) revision of a hospital budget, 3) an enforcement action, and 4) approval of a performance improvement plan. Requires hospitals annually submit to the Board certain information including, financial, utilization, volume, and budgets, as well as other information the Board determines relevant to the budget review process. Requires hospitals submit audited financial statements to the Board, for the Board to conduct review of each hospital's proposed budget, and establishes certain actions the Board must take during the review process. Establishes violations and enforcement. Establishes in 2026, if the Board determines a hospital's actual annual cost growth exceeded the spending benchmark, the Board is required to send notice to the hospital of the findings and require the hospital submit a performance improvement plan within 45 days. Requires the Board promulgate additional regulations and written guidance on the performance improvement plan process. Requires a proposed performance improvement plan submitted by a hospital, which must include identifying the causes of the cost growth, specific strategies, adjustments, and action steps to implement cost performance, and identifiable and measurable expected outcomes and a timetable for implementation not to exceed 12 months. Establishes the process if the performance improvement plan is unacceptable or incomplete, and if needed for the Board to require the hospital to submit to the budget approval process. Establishes the process and requirements if a hospital has undertaken a performance improvement plan and failed to show progress, or is not successful. Establishes the requirements for an approved hospital budget, and the criteria for the Board to amend or not amend. Establishes when a hospital no longer has to go through the budget approval process, and the appeal process of a Board decision. Establishes civil penalties when violations meet certain criteria, and requirements for open meetings and records. Requires the Board annually convene at least 1 public hearing per hospital. Establishes a temporary pricing measure for calendar years 2025 and 2026. Prohibits a hospital from charging a payer, purchaser, insurer, or public program an amount that exceeds the greater of 2% of Core CPI plus 1% over rates from the previous year. Prohibits a hospital from charging or collecting from a patient any amount that exceeds the amount permitted under this measure. Exempts a hospital that serves less than 5% Medicare eligible patients per year or a hospital that derives 45% or more of its revenue from medicaid or uninsured patients. Note: this measure was amended and replaced the temporary reference pricing provision with a cost growth containment measure.
sponsor: Rep. Valerie Longhurst (D), Sen. Bryan Townsend (D)

summary: This measure establishes that the Delaware Health Care Commission shall coordinate with the Delaware Economic and Financial Advisory Council (DEFAC) Health Care Spending Benchmark Subcommittee to establish and monitor the state health care spending and quality benchmarks. The benchmark shall be the per capita potential gross state product (PGSP) growth rate, to be calculated as the sum of the expected growth in national labor force productivity, plus the expected growth in Delaware's civilian labor force, plus the expected national inflation, minus Delaware's expected population growth. The Subcommittee shall monitor the components of the PGSP or other approved benchmark methodology and make arrangements and recommendations as to whether and how the benchmark methdology and/or growth rate should change. DEFAC shall report annually to the Governor and Commission regarding any approved changes to the benchmark. The Health Care Commission shall set quality benchmarks and review the methodology used to establish quality benchmarks every three years. The Commission shall engage health care rpoviders and community partners to develop strategies to reduce variation in cost and quality to help the state perform relative to the spending and quality benchmarks.

This measure modifies the Health Care Cost Growth Target Program and the Health Care Cost Growth Target Implementation Committee. Under these amendments, the term "Health Care Cost Growth Benchmark" is modified to "Health Care Cost Growth Target," "Health Care Cost Growth Benchmark Implementation Committee" is modified to "Health Care Cost Growth Target Implementation Committee," and “total health expenditures” may include expenditures for care provided to out-of-state residents by in-state providers to the extent practicable. The bill requires the Oregon Health Authority (OHA) to adopt by rule criteria for waiving the requirement that payers or providers undertake a performance improvement plan if necessitated by unforeseen market conditions or other equitable factors, and requires OHA to collaborate with payers and providers on performance improvement plans and specifies required elements of the plan. The bill also requires OHA to adopt by rule criteria for imposing financial penalties on providers or payers who exceed the cost growth target without reasonable cause in three out of five calendar years or on any provider or payer who does not participate in the program. Additionally, the bill prohibits OHA from imposing penalties before Jan. 1, 2026 for performance during calendar years 2021 to 2025.

This measure has language stripped out that establishes the Health Spending Transparency and Containment Program to maintain an annual health care cost growth target that will be used as a voluntary benchmark to measure Rhode Island health care spending performance relative to the target, which performance will be publicly reported annually. The program will use data to determine what factors are causing increased health spending in the state, and create actionable analysis to drive changes in practice and policy and develop cost reduction strategies.

This measure requires the Washington Health Care Authority to establish the Health Care Cost Transparency Board to analyze total health care expenditures, identify trends in health care cost growth, and establish a health care cost growth benchmark. The board shall establish an advisory committee on data issues and an advisory committee of health care providers and health plans. The board will determine the types and sources of data necessary to calculate the benchmark and the method for data collection. The board may contract with a private, non-profit entity to administer the board and carry out its responsibilities

This measure increases the capacity of the Health Care Cost Transparency Board. The bill increases the membership of the Transparency Board's Health Care Stakeholder Advisory Committee by adding members representing consumers, labor purchasers, and employer purchasers. The Board may require data collection from payers and providers to annually calculate total health care expenditures and cost growth, establish the cost growth benchmark, and analyze the impact of cost drivers on health care spending. The Board is also directed to conduct a study of costs from nonprofit providers and payers not included in total health care expenditures. The bill expands the categories of data and cost drivers the Board may use in its analyses. The state Health Care Authority is authorized to conduct activities necessary to support the Board, including data collection and analysis and the enforcement of performance improvement plan submissions. The Board may require that payers or health care providers that frequently exceed the cost growth benchmark without a reasonable justification submit a performance improvement plan or pay a civil fine unless the provider is composed of 25 or fewer health care professionals. As of 2/6/204, HB 1508 has been amended to direct the Board to annually hold a public hearing to discuss the growth in total health care expenditures in relation to the cost growth benchmark and identify payers or providers whose cost growth exceeded the health care cost growth benchmark.
sponsor: Rep. Nicole Macri (D) et al. / Sen. June Robinson (D) et al.

summary: This measure, effective July 1, 2024, bans facility fees for outpatient telehealth and preventive services in an off-campus hospital location with some exemptions. The legislation also requires patient notifications of a facility fee, makes it a deceptive practice to impose a facility fee when otherwise prohibited, requires reporting from the All-Payer Claims Database (APCD) on facility fees, and requires the state to report by December 2023 on the impact of facility fees.
sponsor: Rep. Emily Sirota (D), Rep. Andrew Boesenecker (D), Sen. Kyle Mullica (D), Sen. Lisa Cutter (D)

summary: This measure repeals existing nursing facility provider fee and intermediate care facility service fee, instead requiring the Colorado healthcare affordability and sustainability enterprise (CHASE) to charge and collect new healthcare affordability and sustainability nursing facility provider fee and intermediate care facility fee. Creates a facility provider fee enterprise support board to support fee implementation. This measure also makes clarifying amendments, and renames the the existing healthcare affordability and sustainability fee and healthcare affordability and sustainability fund to be the healthcare affordability and sustainability hospital provider fee and the healthcare affordability and sustainability hospital provider fee cash fund.
sponsor: Sen. Jeff Bridges (D), Sen. Judith Amabile (D), Rep. Shannon Bird (D), Rep. Emily Sirota (D)

summary: This measure, effective July 1, 2024, expands the current ban on facility fees to on-campus outpatient current procedural terminology evaluation and management (CPT E/M) codes and assessment and management (CPT A/M) code services, with exceptions for the emergency department and observations stays for certain services. The on-campus ban would not apply if the hospital or health system has a contract in effect as of July 1, 2024 that provides reimbursement for those fees until the date of expiration, renewal or amendment, whichever date is the earliest. The measure requires facility fees reporting to OHS disaggregated by off-campus and on-campus. The measure eliminates a provision that stated that a violation by a hospital or health system was subject to the Connecticut unfair trade practices act and includes a section allowing the OHS executive director to issue a notice of violation and impose a fine of up to $1000, except in the case of isolated clerical or electronic billing errors. It also permits the executive director to issue a cease-and-desist order in certain circumstances. Note: This is a larger bill that contains several provisions. Other provisions are included in the appropriate tab.
sponsor: Rep. Robyn Porter (D), Rep. Eleni Kavros DeGraw (D), Rep. Tammy Nuccio (R)

summary: This measure extends telehealth provisions adopted during the COVID-19 pandemic until June 30, 2027, including a provision that prohibits telehealth providers from charging a facility fee for a telehealth service.

This measure prohibits hospital-based off campus emergency departments from identifying to the public as an urgent care center, and requires such departments to post signs containing specified statements including the facility's average facility fee.

This measure requires that a qualified provider that is part of a non-profit hospital system and that provides services in an office-based setting submit its bills on an individual provider form rather than an institutional provider form. It also requires net patient revenue (NPR) and paid claims reporting by hospitals, including NPR and total number of paid claims from facility fees separately for inpatient and outpatient services by payer type, effective January 1, 2025. Note: This is a larger bill that contains several provisions. Other provisions are included in the appropriate tab.
sponsor: Rep. Donna Schaibley (R), Rep. Matthew S. Lehman (R), Rep. Kyle Pierce (R)

summary: This measure requires that if a hospital charges an outpatient facility fee, the hospital provide the patient with a written notice, separate from any other forms or notices. The patient must sign this notice before receiving services. The notice, a full template of which is available in the measure, includes the address and contact information of a “no facility fee location” where the patient can see a provider at a location which does not charge a facility fee. The hospital must provide a range of potential facility fees based on typical or average facility fees for the same or similar appointments. Annually, each hospital will report to the Health Services Cost Review Commission a list of the hospital based, rate-regulated outpatient services provided by the hospital. The Health Services Cost Review Commission will publish this information online and provide it to the Maryland Insurance Administration and the Health Education and Advocacy Unit in the Office of the Attorney General.
sponsor: Del. Robbyn Lewis (D) / Sen. Delores Goodwin Kelley (D)

summary: This measure amends the definition of "hospital" to require a hospital located outside Maryland that provides outpatient services to patients in the state to provide written notice regarding outpatient facility fees under certain circumstances. The bill amends the required contents of the written notice regarding outpatient facility fees and requires the Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission to study and make recommendations regarding hospital outpatient facility fees.

This measure requires that the state APCD produce and post by January 1, 2024, on its publicly accessible website “a report on the payments for facility fees made by payors to the extent that payment information is already reported to the organization.” The legislation also establishes a task force to study a range of issues on facility fees and to make recommendations based on the information reviewed by the task force. These provisions are effective July 6, 2023.
sponsor: Sen. Troy Jackson (D), Sen. Joe Baldacci (D), Sen. Mattie

summary: This measure implements certain recommendations of the Task Force to Evaluate the Impact of Facility Fees on Patients. The bill prohibits the charging of a facility fee by a health care entity for telehealth services unless the patient is physically present in a hospital-based facility when receiving those telehealth services. The bill requires a health care entity to post notice, and whether a facility fee will be charged for services, in a location accessible to patients and on the entity’s website if the health care entity is a hospital-based facility that is part of a hospital or health system. The bill also requires the Maine Health Data Organization to post information on its website relating to facility fees. As of 4/11/2024, this measure was amended to change the title and remove the requirement that the health care entity disclose information related to the financial liability of a patient if a facility fee is charged. The amendment also removes the provisions prohibiting the charging of a facility fee by a health care entity for telehealth services unless the patient is physically present in a hospital-based facility when receiving those telehealth services.
sponsor: Joint Standing Committee on Health Coverage, Insurance and Financial Services

summary: This measure requires all health insurance and employee benefit plans in the state provide coverage for telemedicine services, and reimburse providers who are out-of-network for telemedicine services. Establishes an originating site is eligible to receive a facility fee, but facility fees are not payable to distant sites; patients in a patient-to-provider consultation shall not be entitled to receive a facility fee.
sponsor: Sen. J Walter Michel (R), Rep. Athena Hollins (DFL), Rep. Sandra Feist (DFL)

summary: This measure would amend the Medicaid facility fee reimbursement rate for freestanding birthing centers to ensure that the rate is comparable to that for hospitals.

This measure prohibits a health care professional providing telehealth services from charging a health plan issuer covering telehealth services a facility fee, an origination fee, or any fee associated with the cost of the equipment used at the provider site to provide telehealth services. A health care professional may charge a health plan issuer for durable medical equipment used at a patient or client site.

This measure requires freestanding emergency medical care facilities associated with hospitals that provide testing or vaccination for an infectious disease based on a state of disaster to disclose to each patient the prices the facility charges for the test or vaccine and any facility fees, supply costs, and other costs associated with the test or vaccine. The bill also prohibits a facility is prohibited from charging an individual an "unconscionable price" for a product or service provided at the facility; or knowingly or intentionally charging a third-party payor, including a health benefit plan insurer, a price higher than the price charged to an individual for the same product or service based on the payor ’s liability for payment or partial payment of the product or service.

This is the state budget bill. The measure directs the Department of Medical Assistance Services to increase the telehealth originating site facility fee to 100% of the Medicare rate and reflect changes annually based on any changes in the Medicare rate. Federally Qualified Health Centers and Rural Health Centers are exempt from this reimbursement change.
sponsor: Rep. Luke Torian (D) / Sen. Thomas Norment (R)

summary: This measure requires health carriers to reimburse a provider for a health care service provided to a covered person through telemedicine at the same rate as if the health care service was provided in person by the provider. Hospitals, hospital systems, telemedicine companies, and provider groups consisting of 11 or more providers may elect to negotiate a reimbursement rate for telemedicine services that differs from the reimbursement rate for in-person services. Reimbursement for facility fees must be subject to a negotiated agreement between the originating site and the health plan.

This measure requires any health plan; health plan offered to employees, school employees, or their dependents; behavioral health administrative services organizations and managed care organizations; and contracts with the state health care authority to reimburse a provider for a health care service provided to a covered person through telemedicine the same amount of compensation the carrier would pay the provider if the service was provided in person. Hospitals, hospital systems, telemedicine companies and provider groups of eleven or more providers may elect to negotiate an amount of compensation for telemedicine services that differs from the amount of compensation for in-person services. Any originating site for a telemedicine health care service may charge a facility fee for infrastructure and preparation of the patient, and reimbursement for a facility fee must be negotiated between the originating site and the health plan.
This measure prohibits a hospital that is an originating site or distant site for audio-only telemedicine from charging a facility fee.

This measure requires an insurer who issues or renews a policy after July 1, 2020, to provide coverage of health care services provided through telehealth services if those same services are covered through face-to-face consultation by the policy. An originating site may charge an insurer a site fee.

This measure prohibits any person reporting any medical debt information to any consumer reporting agency. Prohibits a consumer reporting agency from making a consumer report that they know contains information related to a consumer's medical debt.

This measure updates the definition of "extraordinary collection action" (ECA) by removing its relationship to a Financial Assistance Policy, and establishes an exemption for engaging in an ECA around the sale of medical debt if it meets criteria.

This appropriation appropriates $15 million to the Department of Healthcare and Family Services from the Medical Debt Relief Pilot Program Fund for grants and administrative costs associated with the pilot program for the purchase of medical debt.
sponsor: Sen. Elgie R Sims, Jr (D), Sen. Mattie Hunter (D), Rep. Emanuel "Chris" Welch (D), Rep. Robyn Gabel (D)

summary: This measure establishes requirements for a complaint for a money judgment, and prohibits a lien on owner-occupied residential property as a result of a breach of contract for the payment of medical debt.
sponsor: Sen. Sara Love (D), Rep. Elizabeth Embry (D), Rep. Dalya Attar (D), Rep. Adrian Boafo (D)

summary: This measure prohibits a consumer reporting agency from making, creating, or furnishing any consumer report with adverse information that includes medical debt, a collection action related to medical debt, or maintaining a file on a consumer with medical debt information or collection action against to collect medical debt. Prohibits any person from using medical debt information in a consumer report to make a determination regarding creditworthiness. Requires each hospital annually submit to the Commission: 1) the hospital's policy on the collection of debts owed to patients, and 2) a report including certain information. Requires policies submitted to the commission meet certain criteria, establish certain actions, and prohibit certain actions. Requires hospitals have installment payment plans that meet certain criteria, and inform patients of this option. Establishes compliance for these payment plans. Establishes compliance with the measure, and establishes the process for hospitals taking certain actions. Requires by a certain date hospitals instruct consumer reporting agencies delete the adverse information about patient medical debt that they had previously reported. Establishes a person whose primary business is providing medical services, products, or devices, or the person's agent or assignee: 1) prohibit the disclosure of any portion of a medical debt to a consumer reporting agency, and 2) require in any contract with a collection entity regarding medical debt a provision prohibiting the disclosure of any portion of the medical debt to a consumer reporting agency. Establishes after a certain date any contract entered into that does not include the provisions required in this measure are void and unenforceable.
sponsor: Del. Julie Palakovich Carr (D), Sen. Clarence K Lam (D)

summary: This measure requires each hospital submit a report on medical debt to a commission. Requires hospitals to dismiss pending actions against patients if the medical debt was sold, and prohibits the hospital from taking collection actions or collecting on judgements against patients for medical debt that was sold. Establishes a hospital may sell certain medical debt to a governmental unit or entity under contract with the unit for the sole purpose of canceling the debt.

This measure prohibits reporting medical debt on a consumer report, establishes the definition of medical debt, and prohibits a debt collector, debt buyer, or entity providing health care services reporting medical debt to a consumer reporting agency.

This measure includes provisions not related to medical debt. This measure establishes the Medical Debt Relief Program, which has the purpose of discharging medical debt for eligible residents by a contracted medical debt relief coordinator, and administered by the State Treasurer. Establishes the requirements of the relief, the coordinator, and monies appropriated.

This measure includes provisions not related to medical debt such as Rx. This summary only includes the medical debt information. This measure prohibits a hospital taking certain actions against a covered medical debt, if the hospital is not in compliance with certain provisions of the measure. Establishes a debtor may file a claim with the Bureau of Consumer Protection in the Office of the Attorney General if they believe a hospital is in violation. Establishes the requirements of the Bureau, and penalties for violations.
sponsor: Sen. Rochelle Nguyen (D), Sen. Jeff Stone (R), Sen. Robin Titus (R)

summary: This measures clarifies the definition of medical debt to be related to health care services, products or devices provided to a person by a hospital, health care professional, or ambulance service. Establishes criteria under which medical debt is not.

This measure prohibits providers or debt collection service from reporting to a credit bureau a patient's medical debt, and prohibits a consumer reporting agency from including medical debt in a consumer report. Establishes a court may declare the medical debt void and uncollectible.
sponsor: Sen. Wlnsvey Campos (D), Rep. Nathan Sosa (D)

summary: This measure limits interest on medical debt, and applies only to new debt incurred after the effective date.
sponsor: Rep. Mary Ann Shallcross Smith (D), Rep. Art Handy (D), Rep. Jenni Furtado (D), Rep. Earl Read (D)

summary: This measure adds medical debt to the definition of what a credit report cannot include, and prohibits courts from certain collection actions due to medical debt. Establishes violations.
sponsor: Rep. Mary Ann Shallcross Smith (D), Rep. Deborah A Fellela (D), Rep. George A Nardone (R), Rep. Michael Chippendale (R)

summary: This measure establishes a credit report does not include any information for medical debt. Prohibits certain extraordinary collection actions.
sponsor: Sen. Jacob Bissaillon (D), Sen. Dominick J Ruggerio (D), Sen. Valarie J Lawson (D), Sen. Melissa A Murray (D)

summary: This measure prohibits a large health care facility or medical debt buyer from charging interest or late fees on medical debt for 90 days and limits interest to 3%. Prohibits any medical creditor or medical debt collector taking certain extraordinary collection actions to collect medical debt. Prohibits a medical creditor from selling medical debt to a buyer unless certain criteria are met. Prohibits a medical creditor or medical debt collector taking any extraordinary collection action until 120 days following the final invoice, and requires at least 30 days before taking an extraordinary collection action providing notice.

This measure appropriates state general funds to the State Treasurer for the purpose of contracting with a nonprofit entity to acquire and repay certain medical debts. Establishes requirements of the State Treasurer and criteria for one to obtain debt relief. Prohibits a credit reporting agency from reporting or maintaining medical debt information, and a large health care facility from reporting or furnishing medical debt information to a credit reporting agency. Establishes that a large health care facility may sell or transfer medical debt to an organization that is exempt from taxation and for the purpose of abolishing the medical debt. Permits a tax-exempt organization from accessing a consumer's credit report without permission for the purpose of determining eligibility for the abolition of medical debt.
sponsor: Sen. Virginia Lyons (D), Sen. Philip Baruth (D/P), Sen. Scott Beck (R), Sen. Patrick Brennan (R)

summary: This measure updates the definition of medical debt. Prohibits a health care provider, facility, licensed collection agency, and other entities and people from furnishing any information regarding medical debt to a consumer credit reporting agency, and outlines violations to this provision. Establishes what collection agents can and cannot do regarding medical debt.
sponsor: Sen. Marcus Riccelli (D), Sen. Jessica Bateman (D), Rep. Joe Timmons (D), Rep. Jamila Taylor (D)

summary: This measure has language stripped out that would have required that reimbursement for specific medical equipment be priced at the lesser of an amount not exceeding 80% of the lowest maximum allowance for California established by the federal Medicare program, the amount billed pursuant to the California Code of Regulations, or the guaranteed acquisition cost plus a percentage markup to be established by the department

This measure creates a health care cost oversight task force and charges it with review of multiple topics, including recommendations on reduction of health care costs and concentration of health care providers and insurers, and review of data that will be submitted to it from several departments. It requires the Office of the Secretary of Family and Social Services, before November 1, 2023, to research and compile data concerning Medicaid reimbursement rates for Indiana and all other states and the national reimbursement rate average; requires the Department of Insurance to contract with a third party to calculate Indiana nonprofit hospital system's prices categorized by– self-funded, fully-insured, and individual market prices, and the combined prices of those categories as a percentage of Medicare prices for calendar years 2021, 2022, and 2023; requires non-profit hospital systems to report that same information each subsequent year with the charge information required by CMS before March 1, 2024 and before March 1 of each subsequent year; and requires the third party contractor, by November 1, 2024 and by November 1 of each subsequent year, to compare certain Indiana nonprofit hospital system facility pricing information with 285% of Medicare. The legislation also requires the submission of specific claims data by payers to the Department of Insurance. Note: This is a larger bill that contains several provisions. Other provisions are included in the appropriate tab.
sponsor: Rep. Donna Schaibley (R), Rep. Matthew S. Lehman (R), and Rep. Kyle Pierce (R)

summary: This measure includes provisions unrelated to reference-based pricing and health system costs. This measure requires each hospital file with the state department a report for the preceding fiscal years, which must contain certain information, including financial, ownership, and control information. Establishes a hospital that failed to file is required to pay a fine. Requires a non profit hospital system annually submit audited financial statements to the state department for the preceding two years, and establishes penalties for failure to submit. Requires the office of management and budget develop a methodology to conduct a study of commercial inpatient hospital prices and outpatient hospital prices including hospital pricing data from the 2023 and 2024 calendar years to determine Indiana's statewide average inpatient and outpatient hospital price. Requires the office present the methodology to the budget committee for review. Requires before June 30, 2026, the office conduct the study using the methodology that was reviewed by the budget committee. Requires the office submit a report to the governor and general assembly on their findings in the study. Requires a hospital provide the office with any data requested by the office to conduct the study. Establishes not later than June 30, 2020, a nonprofit hospital system's aggregate average inpatient and outpatient hospital prices must be at least equal to or less than the statewide average inpatient and outpatient hospital prices determined by the office. Violation will result in forfeiture of the nonprofit hospitals state nonprofit tax status for at least one year, and establishes the process for reestablishment of the state tax status. Requires each nonprofit hospital annually provide the state department with the entirety of the hospital's federal Form 990, Schedule H, including the hospital's worksheets to complete the Schedule H. Requires the state department submit the forms provided by a nonprofit hospital to the health care cost oversight task force. Establishes fines for nonprofit hospitals that fail to submit the forms required to the state department. Requires an insurer, health maintenance organization, or a third party administrator disclose certain information to the policyholder or subscriber, and for those entity to submit that information to the executive director of the all payer claims database for inclusion in the database. Requires the department examine for any alleged violations. Requires by July 1, 2026 the office of management and budget study the effect and fiscal impact of requiring physician reimbursement rates under a commercial health plan to be at a minimum rate, and for the office to report the findings to the governor and general assembly. Requires on September 1, 2025 for a nonprofit hospital system, and September 1, 2026 for a hospital that is not a nonprofit, offer a direct to employer health care arrangement that is at or below 260% of full Medicare. Establishes how the benchmark be calculated, and the criteria that at least one must be met for a nonprofit hospital system to meet the requirement. Requires a nonprofit hospital system cooperate with an audit by the state to determine compliance, and establishes violations and penalties for noncompliance. Establishes the requirements and process for claims data requested by a contract holder to a direct to employer health care arrangement, and the requirements of what must be included in the claims data. Establishes process for submitting complaints to the state for this arrangement.
sponsor: Rep. Martin Cabaugh (R), Rep. Julie McGuire (R), Rep. Benjamin Smaltz (R)

summary: This measure includes a provision that requires the Department of Corrections, or its contracted medical provider, to pay to a medical provider for any and all incarcerated persons from a correctional or detention facility an amount based upon negotiated fees as agreed to by the medical care service providers and the department and/or its contracted medical provider. In the absence of negotiated discounted fee schedule, medical care service providers will be paid by the department, or its contracted medical service provider, an amount no greater than the reimbursement rate applicable based on the Mississippi Medicaid reimbursement rate.

This measure includes a provision that establishes that the minimum allowable reimbursement rate an insurer can reimburse an out of network ambulance service provider is set at the rates approved by a local governmental entity in the jurisdiction in which the covered health care services originates. If local governmental rates are not set then the rates are to be set as the lesser of either 325% of the current published rate for ambulance services or the ambulance service provider's billed charges. The out of network rates cannot exceed the in network rates. This measure modifies the definition of health care benefit plan to include government sponsored self insured plans and establishes that a health care benefit plan does not include any health plans offered by a contracted entity that provides coverage to members of the state Medicaid program.
sponsor: Rep. Kevin Wallace (R), Rep. Paul Rosino (R)

summary: This measure establishes standards for global hospital budgets that reflect the implementation of reference-based pricing and total cost of care targets. Requires the Green Mountain Care Board establish by 2028 global hospital budgets for hospitals that are not critical access, and by 2030 budgets for all hospitals. Requires the Board establish reference-based prices as a percentage of Medicare, with the option in the future to reference reasonable rates of growth separate from Medicare. Requires the Board consider certain factors when establishes reference-based prices, requires the Board establish the amounts that health insurers pay to hospitals by fiscal year 2027, and ensure implementation does not allow hospitals to charge or collect from patients any amount in excess of the reference-based amount. Requires the Board in collaboration with the Department of Financial Regulation monitor the implementation of reference-based pricing, to ensure decreased prices paid to hospital are commensurate with decreases in health insurance premiums. Requires the Board post its findings annually on its website, and identify factors that would lead to terminating the use of reference-based pricing in one or more hospitals. Establishes the Agency of Human Services in consultation with the Board may implement reference-based pricing for services delivered outside a hospital such as primary care, and may increase or decrease the percentage of Medicare or another benchmark as appropriate. Requires hospitals file certain information and proposals to the Board, such as administration compensation and ways to support independent providers. Requires the Board consider certain plans when reviewing hospitals' budgets, as well as certain hospital information. Establishes the requirements of hospital budgets including reflecting reference-based pricing. Requires by fiscal year 2028, the Board establish global hospital budgets for hospitals, excluding critical access hospitals, and by 2030 budgets for all hospitals. Requires the board in consultation with the Vermont Program for Quality in Health Care utilize certain mechanisms to measure certain metrics. Requires notice of intent to the Board and certain stakeholders if a hospital proposes to reduce or eliminate any service to comply with the budget, and establishes the requirements of what is in the notice of intent. Establishes the board may evaluate the notice, and may modify the hospitals' budget or take action deemed appropriate to preserve the necessary services. Requires the Board in consultation with the Department of Financial Regulation monitor the implementation of any authorized decrease in hospital services to determine the benefit. Establishes the Board may review and evaluate the structure of a hospital network to determine certain factors, investigate the financial operations of a hospital network, and make recommendations. Requires certain agencies and stakeholders in the State develop an integrated Statewide Health Care Delivery Plan that meets certain requirements, criteria, and factors, including an annual cost growth rate and target. Requires certain agencies provide expertise, collect data and engage with stakeholders over a certain time period, and by certain deadlines prepare and present the Plan to the legislature. Establishes the Health Care Delivery Advisory Committee to establish, evaluation, collaborate, advise, and provide certain items, including an affordability benchmark. Establishes the composition of the Health Care Delivery Advisory Committee. Establishes the Vermont Steering Committee for Comprehensive Primary Health Care. Establishes the committee members and requirements of the committee. Requires the Agency of Human Services collaborate with the Health Information Exchange Steering Committee in the development of an integrated system of clinical and claims data to meet certain criteria, and establishes the Agency's process to meet and support certain items. Requires health insurers provide certain data, and the Agency provide access to data to State agencies and health care providers as needed to meet the Statewide Health Care Delivery Plan. Requires the Agency of Human Services provide an update to the legislature annually. Requires the Agency of Human Services facilitate collaboration and coordination among health care providers in developing rapid responses to urgent financial pressures facing the system system, and identify opportunities to increase efficiency, improve quality, reduce spending on prescription drugs, and increase access to essential services. Requires facilitating and supervising participation of hospitals and other providers as necessary for collaboration to be afforded state-action immunity under applicable federal and state antitrust laws. Requires the agency report on proposed reductions, timing, and accountability measures to the legislature by a certain date. Requires the agency identify specific outcome measures. Requires the Agency of Human Services award grants to hospital that actively participate in health care transformation efforts to achieve certain goals. Requires the Agency of Human Services explore opportunities to retain capabilities developed by or on behalf of accountable care organizations funded by state or federal monies, and for the Agency to submit a report on findings to the Health Reform Oversight Committee. Requires the Agency of Human Services and the Green Mountain Care Board provide an update to the legislature regarding the Implementation of this measure, including certain topics and information. Appropriates funds.
sponsor: Senate Committee on Health and Welfare

summary: This measure requires certain hospitals receiving payment through Medicaid to contract with the Health Care Authority (Public Employees Benefits Board and School Employee Benefits Board) when those certain hospitals receive a good faith offer, with exceptions. Establishes that beginning on Jan. 1, 2027, reimbursement to any in-network provider or facility for inpatient or outpatient hospital services be the lesser of the billed charges, the contractor's rate, or 200% of Medicare; for children's hospitals, reimbursement be the lesser of the billed charges, the contractor's rate, or 150% of Medicare (if in King county), or 190% of Medicare (if in Pierce county); for rural hospitals, reimbursement may not be less than 101% of allowable costs; for in-network primary care services not less than 150% of Medicare; for in-network non facility-based behavioral health services not less than 150% of Medicare. For out-of-network inpatient and outpatient hospital services, reimbursement be the lesser of the billed charges, the contractor's rate, or 185% of Medicare; for children's hospitals, reimbursement be the lesser of the billed charges, the contractor's rate, or 135% of Medicare (if in King county), or 175% of Medicare (if in Pierce county). Establishes certain hospitals are exempt. Establishes this measure does not prohibit a contractor from reimbursing a hospital through a non fee-for-service payment methodology, as long as certain criteria are met. Requires premiums take into account changes in reimbursement for hospital, primary care, and behavioral health services anticipated to result from the application of this section of the measure. Requires the contractor provide cost and quality information and data to the authority, and prohibits a contractor from entering into an agreement with a provider or third party restricting the contractor from providing data. Requires by Dec. 31, 2030 the authority in consultation with the insurance commissioner provide a report analyzing the impacts of this measure and certain information. Requires a second report by December 31, 2034 from the authority in consultation with the insurance commissioner with certain information. Establishes reimbursement for inpatient and outpatient services does not include charges for professional services. Establishes the authority may adopts rules to implement the measure.
sponsor: Sen. June Robinson (D), Sen. Paul Harris (R), Rep. Nicole Macri (D), Rep. Liz Berry (D)

summary: This measure removes: 1) the requirement that a healthcare insurer or transportation benefit manager pay 250% of Medicare Ambulance Fee Schedule, 2) the requirement an ambulance provider accept the payment in full, 3) the prohibition of an ambulance provider balance billing or otherwise demanding a payment from the subscriber other than a deductible, copayment, or coinsurance required under the subscriber's health benefit plan. Establishes by July 1, 2025 the Arkansas Ambulance Association collect the rates that are approved or contracted between an ambulance provider and local government entity, and submitted annual to the commissioner. Establishes a finding by the General Assembly that it is necessary to resolve a conflict regarding in-network and out-of-network reimbursement rates for ambulance services, the conflict is causing confusion amongst several stakeholders, that this measure is necessary to alleviate confusion concerning reimbursement rates for ambulance services, an emergency is declared to exist, and the measure is necessary for the public peace, health, and safety.
sponsor: Rep. Lee Johnson (R), Rep. Mark Perry (D), Sen. Missy Irvin (R)

summary: This measure establishes that in the absence of ambulance rates set, the minimum allowable rate of reimbursement is the lesser of: 1) 325% of the Medicare Ambulance Fee Schedule, Arkansas Rural Rate, or 2) the provider's billed charges. Establishes a finding by the General Assembly that it is necessary to resolve a conflict regarding in-network and out-of-network reimbursement rates for ambulance services, the conflict is causing confusion amongst several stakeholders, that this measure is necessary to alleviate confusion concerning reimbursement rates for ambulance services, an emergency is declared to exist, and the measure is necessary for the public peace, health, and safety,
sponsor: Rep. Lee Johnson (R), Rep. Mark Perry (D), Sen. Missy Irvin (R)

summary: This measure, among other things, directs the Department of Insurance and Financial Institutions to develop arbitration procedures for surprise out-of-network bill disputes between enrollees, health insurers and health care providers. Enrollees may submit arbitration requests to the Department for review.

This measure requires health insurers provide notice in each explanation of benefits or similar notice with the statutory right to dispute an out-of-network surprise bill as long as they are not subject to an independent dispute resolutions under federal law.

This measure stipulates that an enrollee receiving medically necessary treatment for a mental health or substance use disorder from a 988 center, mobile crisis team, or other provider of behavioral crisis services outside the plan network shall not pay more than the same cost-sharing that the enrollee would pay for the same covered services from an in-network provider. An out-of-network 988 center, mobile crisis team, or other provider of behavioral health crisis services shall not bill or collect an amount from the enrollee for services except for the in-network cost-sharing amount.

This measure changes current state law to align with the federal "No Surprises Act" by: allowing a covered person to request an independent external review of a health care coverage decision determining if services provided by an out-of-network provider or facility are subject to an in-network benefit level of coverage; requiring that payments made for services provided at an in-network facility or by an out-of-network provider be applied to the covered person's in-network deductible; requiring that in-network services, regardless of facility, are covered at the in-network benefit level; and requiring the insurance commissioner to adopt rules concerning disclosure requirements, including a list of services for which a balance bill may not be charged.
sponsor: Rep. Daneya Esgar (D), Rep. Marc Catlin (R)

summary: This measure, effective May 4, 2023, revises medical debt collection practices and makes violating billing practice, surprise billing, and balance billing laws a deceptive trade practice. It also requires providers and facilities to provide an estimate of the total cost of a service to a person that intends to self-pay upon request of the prospective patient.
sponsor: Sen. Lisa Cutter (D), Sen. Sonya Jaquez Lewis (D), and Rep. Mike Weissman (D)

summary: This measure clarifies medically necessary health benefit coverage for prevention, screening, and treatment of behavioral, mental, and substance use disorders. Requires health benefit plans provide coverage for certain services and treatments. Establishes criteria for utilization review, service intensity, level of care, and provider reimbursement.
sponsor: Rep. Kyle Brown (D), Rep. Lindsay Gilchrist (D), Sen. Judy Amabile (D), Sen. Byron Pelton (R)

summary: This measure is part of a larger package on children's mental health. Among other things, it establishes the maximum allowable billable and reimbursable amounts for out-of-network acute inpatient psychiatric services. For these services, a provider may bill up to the greatest of the: (1) in-network rate, (2) usual and customary rate, or (3) Medicare rate. As with existing law for out-of-network emergency services, a provider and carrier may agree to a higher reimbursement rate. The bill makes it a Connecticut Unfair Trade Practices Act violation for a health care provider to “balance bill” an insured for covered out-of-network acute inpatient psychiatric services (i.e., bill more than the collectable cost-sharing under the policy).
This measure provides an option for self-funded healthcare plans, exempt from state regulation under federal law, to opt in to Georgia's Surprise Billing Consumer Protection Act

This measure adds to the Surprise Billing Consumer Protection Act a provision that includes mental health and substance use disorders under medical conditions in the definition of 'emergency medical services'. Medical services rendered after an individual is stabilized are also included under the 'emergency medical services' definition.

Previously, under Illinois law, protections for non-emergency services emergency services provided by out-of-network providers at in-network facilities were limited to designated specialties (radiology, anesthesiology, pathology, neonatology, and emergency physicians). This measure applies protections to all covered ancillary reasons. It also removes the restriction around holding consumers harmless only for facility-based providers. It specifies that balance billing law does not apply to air or ground ambulance and gives the Department of Insurance enforcement authority over any balance or surprise billing covered under the No Surprises Act.
This measure specifies that a provider can satisfy state requirements for a good faith estimate of non-emergency health care services based on fulfilling requirements in NSA.

This measure provides that, if a covered individual assigns their rights to benefits for dental services to the provider of the dental services, the dental carrier is to pay the benefits assigned by the covered individual to the provider. The provider must accept compensation from the carrier as payment in full and is prohibited from billing the covered individual for the dental services (except for a copayment, coinsurance, or a deductible amount) if they are in the dental carrier's network. As of 2/20/24, this measure has been amended to change language unrelated to the billing provision.
sponsor: Sen. Liz Brown (R), Sen. Ed Charbonneau (R), Sen. Tyler Johnson (R), Sen. Mike Bohacek (R), Sen. Eric Bassler (R), Sen. Denny Zent (R)

summary: This measure applies the No Surprises Act and gag clause prohibition from the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021 to all insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations that issue policies or contracts for a health benefit plan. It also applies certain transparency requirements around compensation for brokers and consultants and policies around parity in mental health and substance use disorder benefits. It gives the Insurance Commissioner the authority to enforce these provisions.

This measure conforms provisions of state health insurance law with existing federal requirements, including clarifications to federal consumer protection regulations resulting from changes to the No Surprises Act. Carriers that provide benefits for emergency services in a hospital or freestanding medical facility must provide coverage for such services regardless of whether the providers involved are in-network. If a provider is out-of-network, carriers are prohibited from imposing any cost–sharing amount greater than the amount for emergency services provided by an in-network provider. As of 2/6/2024, this measure has been amended to strike and include language unrelated to cost-sharing provisions.
sponsor: House Health and Government Operations Committee / Senate Committee on Finance

summary: This measure requires insurance carriers to provide coverage without imposing any cost-sharing requirements, including copayments, coinsurance, or deductibles for any preventive services.
sponsor: Del. Emily Shetty (D), Del. Heather Bagnall (D); Del Bonnie Cullison (D); Del. Dana Jones (D)

summary: This measure requires health care entities to provide a good faith estimate of the allowed amount under an insured patient's health insurance coverage to be paid by an insurer for services rendered during a single medical encounter. The bill requires the information to be provided within 3 business days of a request from an insured patient to the patient and to their insurer. Health care entities must post notice of a patient's right to request this information in their offices and include notice in a patient's written treatment consent form. Insurers must provide an insured patient with an advanced explanation of benefits within 3 business days of receiving a good faith estimate from a health care entity for medical services. As of 3/13/2024, this measure has been amended to revise disclosure requirements and time frames in which a health care entity is directed to provide a good faith estimate of the cost of medical services rendered during a single medical encounter to uninsured and insured patients. The bill also prohibits a health care entity from initiating or pursuing any collection action against an uninsured patient for items or services unless the health care entity provided a good faith estimate to a patient that requested an estimate.

This measure provides that, under the balance billing prohibition regarding insurer payment of claims, a licensed health care provider rendering hospital, nursing, medical or surgical services is prohibited from including the practice of dentistry.

This measure prohibits an ambulance service provider from collecting or billing more than the covered individual's deductible, coinsurance, copayment, or other cost-sharing amount the covered individual would be responsible if a participating ambulance service provider. Requires health care insurers directly reimburse ambulance services for a covered individual. Establishes if a covered person uses an out-of-network ambulance service provider, the health insurer shall pay the ambulance service provider the lesser of: 1) 250% of Medicare, 2) the ambulance provider's billed charges. Establishes any rate the insurer pays may not be required to include the coinsurance, copayment, and deductible owned or already paid by the covered person. Establishes the insurance commissioner may adopt rules to implement and enforce this section. Requires the department use pagers as a communication method for emergency medical services operation communications.
sponsor: Rep. Robin Weisz (R), Sen. Kristin Roers (R)

summary: This measure prohibits surprise medical bills and balance billing. This bill requires health carriers to cover out-of network emergency services and services provided at an in-network facility by out-of-network providers in the same manner as if the services were provided by an in-network provider or facility and requires the insurer to pay the nonparticipating provider the out-of-network rate less any cost-sharing for the services provided.

This measure stipulates that a covered person receiving inadvertent out-of-network services, or services at an in-network or out-of-network health facility on an emergency or urgent basis, shall not incur greater out-of-pocket costs than would be incurred with an in-network health care provider for covered services. The out-of-network provider shall not bill the covered person except for applicable deductible, copayment, or coinsurance amounts that would apply if the covered person utilized an in-network provider. The measure also revises New Jersey's existing out-of-network arbitration process. It extends the amount of time a carrier and provider have to negotiate from 30 to 60 days. It also changes the price threshold for what triggers arbitration -- if the difference between a carrier's and provider's final offers is $1,000 or higher for a billed amount of $2,500 or $500 or higher for a billed amount less than $2,500 then arbitration is initiated.

As part of the health and mental hygiene budget for the 2022 - 2023 state fiscal year, this measure also includes language to clarify provisions regarding emergency medical services and surprise bills and compliance with the federal No Surprises Act. It requires that payment disputes must be submitted to the independent dispute resolution (IDR) entity within 3 years of the original payment on the claim. It also dds that the IDR entity will consider the “median of the rate recognized by the health care plan to reimburse qualified providers for the same or similar services in the same region that are participating with the health care plan” for establishing a “reasonable fee.” Previously, balance-billing protections attached when the consumer assigned the benefit to the provider. But this measure updates New York's law to hold harmless any enrollees for emergency services and surprise bills and places an explicit prohibition on surprise billing for providers. Finally, it gives the Superintendent of Insurance the authority to assess penalties if an insurer is found to have willfully violated the federal No Surprises Act or certain provisions of Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021.

This measure includes a provision that updates requirements for an insurer or public employee benefit plan to provide certain information to covered individuals for dental care services. Insurers must include an explanation that insured individuals may incur out-of-pocket expenses as a result of the purchase of dental care services, in addition to vision care services or materials, that are not covered services. The explanation must be communicated in a manner and format similar to how the insurer or plan provides information on coverage levels and out-of-pocket expenses that may be incurred under the policy or plan when purchasing out-of-network dental care services or vision care services or materials.

This measure includes a provision that creates external appeals procedures for complaints by insured employees for adverse benefit determinations based on whether an insurer is complying with surprise billing and cost-sharing protections of the Public Health Services Act.

This measure would prevent a health care provider from charging an enrollee of health plan the difference of a bill charged if an enrollee receives a medically necessary health care service for a price lower than the average amount established by the benefit plan. Requires that the insurance carrier count this amount paid by the enrollee to the deductible and annual maximum out-of-pocket expense. Prevents the amount counted to an out-of-pocket deductible and annual maximum out-of-pocket expense from exceeding what an enrollee is required to pay out of pocket under a contracted amount of time; this amount will not be carried over once a new contract begins.
sponsor: Sen. Avery Frix (R), Rep. Suzanne Schreiber (D)

summary: This measure establishes a local government entity, or ambulance service provider operating on its behalf may annually submit to the Insurance Department the ambulance service rates set or approved, whether in contract or ordinance by the local governmental entity. Requires the Department establish and maintain on its public website a database listing all submitted rates. Establishes in the absence of rates, the rates are the lesser of 1) 325% of the published rate for ambulance services established by CMS, 2) the ambulance service provider's billed charges. Requires the department review the data from the database and submit a report by January 1, 2027 to the Governor and the Legislature. Rates provided in this measure expire by December 31, 2027 unless modified by the Legislature.

This measure includes a provision that establishes that an ambulance service provider is prohibited from billing an enrollee for any additional amounts in excess of what an insurer pays for covered services. This measure modifies the definition of health care benefit plan to include government sponsored self insured plans and establishes that a health care benefit plan does not include any health plans offered by a contracted entity that provides coverage to members of the state Medicaid program.
sponsor: Rep. Kevin Wallace (R), Rep. Paul Rosino (R)

summary: This measure provides that if labor and delivery services are provided to an individual insured under a health benefit plan at an out-of-network health care facility due solely to the diversion of the individual from an in-network health care facility during a state or federally declared public health emergency, the health benefit plan or health care service contract: must reimburse the out-of-network provider in accordance with the federal No Surprises Act, may not impose a deductible, out-of-pocket maximum, copay, or coinsurance requirements that exceed what’s applicable to in-network providers, and must provide coverage for emergency medical transports.
sponsor: Rep. Duane Stark (R), Sen. Elizabeth Steiner Hayward (D)

summary: This measure, effective September 1, 2023, allows self-funded employee plans to opt-in to provisions on the prohibition of balance billing and out-of-network dispute resolution procedures.

This measure includes a provision that requires emergency medical service providers and health care facilities to inform patients, before contacting an air medical transport provider, whether that air medical transport provider balance bills for any charge not paid by the patient's health insurer.
sponsor: Rep. Robert Spendlove (R), Sen. Michael Kennedy (R)
